12962583.review:
I'm no stranger to Visual Novels or gaming in general, and while Sunrider probably isn't going to epitomize any element of its genre, it's a solid fun game worth the play at $20, never mind free. 

[h1]The Plot[/h1]

The plot is fairly straightforward, and a lot of tropes are played straight. To the best of my knowledge, no choice can lead you to a failure state (save through choices made in the combat layer); instead, choices decide what kind of a captain you want to be, and to act contrary to built-up ideals at some critical points is harder than to continue to play your beliefs straight (represented by the offering of the other option at a small cost of in-game command points). 

The writing and dialogue isn't really award worthy, but it's certainly playable. I'd even call it better than average for a VN, and the occasional moments where things really come together more than make up for any bland parts.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]

The real meat of the game is its combat. Battles are challenging and rewarding at Captain, one of the six difficulty levels, and different tactical approaches offer different levels of risk and reward on scales from the immediate to the long-term. Much of this is accomplished through the surprisingly deep upgrade system. While there aren't any trees to climb or alternate ships to swap your pilots into, there's plenty of stats to focus on and their synergies can stretch beyond the immediately apparent. Play well, and you'll have enough money to invest in some pretty niche strategies.

[h1]The Characters[/h1]

The game's character work is about on par with its plot work, but it has the benefit of being fleshed out passively as a consequence of the combat. Even if you're not a big fan of the fairly unadventurous tropes many of the characters are built around, you may find it hard to stay mad when they're jamming half the enemy fleet's targeting for you, or sniping missile boats from accross the map. I know I did. 

The in-combat voice clips got on my nerves at first, but they over time they grew on me, and I wound up pretty happy with them as the rampant devestation they heralded increased in scope and range. Not that you can't turn them off; if there's one thing Sunrider isn't wanting for, it's options.

[h1]Bugs/Issues[/h1]

The game has recieved balance and bugfix reports after release, and it's pretty well rounded. There remain one or two potential crashes related to the combat layer; about once in two hours I would guess, you may hit a script bug that quits you to desktop. However, the game has a very robust auto-save system, and a crash will set you back a few seconds at most.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

This game is fun, good looking, free, and dare I say it: well made. Why not pick it up and see if you like it? You've little to lose except a bit of time, and if it grabs you enough to take that from you, wouldn't you say it's earned its price? 

If does take your fancy, consider throwing a bit of coin at the developers' site. There's no requests for donations or cheap monitization gimmicks in the game, and if the money doesn't go straight to rewarding the devs for their good work, it'll most likely go towards designing more quality games.

12961245.review:
Sunrider es una novela visual japonesa (O por lo menos de estilo Anime) que se centra alrededor del Sunrider, una nave de combate del planeta "Cera". Tras ser destruida la ciudad del protagonista por las fuerzas malvadas del Pacto, este busca entender quienes son, por que lo hicieron, y mas importante aun, busca venganza por los millones de personas que murieron en la ciudad principal de Cera, entre ellos, su hermana menor.
Durante todo el juego vas a poder disfrutar de texto de buena calidad, con imagenes bien dibujadas (A mi me gustó el estilo por lo menos, y eso que no soy Otaku), chicas Anime (De las que podras elegir una para que sea tu Waifu, pero actualmente solo de manera mental, pues no es un Jentay), las tetas de Asaga, etc...
El juego, ademas de ser una buena Novela Visual (En las que no tengo mucha experiencia, pero hasta ahora, las que he leido han sido muy buenas) es un juego tactico de combate por turnos, deberas aprender a utilizar los distintos tipos de Ryders (Unos robots espaciales que son piloteados por la tripulacion femenina del Sunrider), luego deberas invertir la ganancia de la batalla en mejoras para tus Ryders, y el Sunrider mismo.
Por ultimo, tus decisiones, basadas en una moral que no se trata del bien y el mal, sino de ser "Moralista" o "Principe" (Representando respectivamente a la persona que va a defender los ideales de la justicia ante todo, y a la persona que va a hacer lo que sea necesario para ganar la guerra) modifican la manera en que progresa la historia (No modifican demasiado a la historia misma, ya que proseguira de una forma u otra hasta lograr tu objetivo [O fallar]) y tu relacion con tus compañeras  (Asaga preferira a un personaje Moralista, Icari probablemente prefiera a un principe [Aunque esto mas al principio, luego se ablanda xD])

En fin, esto se re alargo, si leiste todo lo que escribi, pues ya deberias estar convencido/a de darle una oportunidad, ademas es gratuito! Jugalo, amalo y despues veni a esperar el proximo capitulo (Return of the Holy Empire) conmigo.

12909990.review:
Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is an indie visual novel with a catch. Depending on
the choice you make at the start of the game, you will play anything ranging
from a good visual novel to a terrible turn-based spaceship battle game.  I had
pleasure to try both the former (visual novel difficulty setting) and the
latter (hard difficulty setting). This review is, therefore, split into two
separate sections covering both variations of the game separately.

First of all, I probably would not even consider playing this game if it was
not free, unless I got a strong recommendation from a friend, or the game came
as a part of a bundle; this game being free will only cost you about 1GiB of
bandwidth to play and you should definitely check it out.

Also, thanks to the technology the game is created with (RenPy) this game is
supported across three major operating systems. Sunrider deserves a big plus
just for diversifying Linux gaming ecosystem.

[h1]The great side: visual novel mode[/h1]

As long as visual novels are concerned there’s three things they have going for
them: story, art and sound, and the game does fine at most of them.

[b]Story[/b]

This game has a traditional science fiction setting – in a far future the
humanity has already inhabited most of the galaxy, they have huge spaceships,
warping devices and laser weapons, and, obviously there’s evil guys who try to
take over the same galaxy. The writing is very approachable and easy to follow,
but repetitive, cliché at times. Sunrider being a visual novel, ability to make
some “important” story-altering decisions as the story progresses would be
expected; capability to make the decisions is presented, but they appear to
have no substantial effect to the story at all: throw a girl into a confinement
chamber and you will still find her in your virtual harem sometime soon anyway.

[b]Art[/b]

The story is wrapped into beautiful japanimation-style art, as common to most
of the visual novels. It is clear that much attention was dedicated to it and I
hereby declare art to be the best thing about Sunrider.

[b]Sound[/b]

Unlike the art, the music is in a much worse shape. While the selection of
tracks is quite likeable, they have a severe deficiency that should not have
been overlooked for beta – the tracks lack any form of loudness normalisation.
You will find yourself reaching for volume control to save your ears when a
louder than usually track starts casually raping them.

On the positive side, the characters are voiced! I’m making the Asaga’s “I’m
firing my lasers” my alarm [i]right now[/i]. A big +1 here.

[h1]The bad side: combat mode[/h1]

Now, if you happen to make a mistake and pick any difficulty harder than the
“visual novel”, you will find yourself battling 8-bit sprites better part of
the game instead of indulging in textual pleasures with your virtual harem
and, occasionally, a dude or two. This does not sound like a problem until you
realize there’s only a few types of units available to fight against and they
are all powered by a pretty stupid, suicidal AI (more likely, just a few hard
coded patterns) making the combat mode a lackluster.

[b]Sound[/b]

The playlist in combat mode seems to differ somewhat from the one used for the
visual novel mode. Regardless, music here suffers from the same issues
mentioned in the visual novel part of the review. Moreover, all this is made
worse by the playback of the tracks: they are stopped after each turn and
another randomly selected track is started from the beginning when next turn
comes around. This results in a feeling of discontinuity and, alas, makes it
hard to appreciate the possibly fine music in its full form.

[h1]Misc[/h1]

[b]Bugs[/b]

While I realise this is a beta version, it is still quite easy to encounter a
crasher or two and get thrown back into the main menu losing all your progress
past the last save. Other bugs I found (where’s the “report a bug” button?)
qualify for beta-grade and mostly consist of graphical issues such as
miscalculated text baselines in research fund allocation screen.

---

In conclusion, while I’d like to rate this game as two separate games, Steam
only has a single binary switch. Therefore, unless I rate visual novel part
>8/10, the average score turns out to be less than ½, hence the “thumbs-down”.

12879910.review:
First things first: The game was financed by a Kickstarter campaign and it is absolutely 100% Free. There is no pay to win or pay for cosmetics content.

If you have thought that visual novels were only "weird porn games from Japan" this is the game for you to try.

Now about the game. It is a visual novel interpersed with tactical hex based mech and spaceship battles. The story is suprisingly good, if rather silly and animesque. Girls are cute but some of the personalities are a bit too archetypal, if you understand what words: Tsundere, class president, genki girl and a Rei clone mean you will be very satisfied. The game doesn´t have any "excessivelly romantic" content in the steam version. The music is also great and fits the game perfectly. The same cannot unfortunately said about voice acting (combat only), but having any in a 40 000$ indie game is amazing.

The main gameplay of the game is a turn and hex based spaceship and mech combat simulator, think gundam but you on the commanders seat. It could be compared to Fire Emblem or advance wars. Every girl has a unique mech and you need to balance their actions accurately to win the battles. expect about 10-15hrs for a playthrough.

All in all a positive suprise of a game, but still a work in progress. The game currently covers 2 out of 3 chapters, and a final release is predicted somewhere in the spring 2015. The game doesn´t have any game breaking bugs and has a small but helpfull dev-team. Definatly worth your time unless you are critically allergic to anime and related tropes.

8/10
Good:
Excelent battle engine
Mechs
Girls
Upgrade system
Feels like a good light hearted mecha-anime.
Music

Bad:
Some balance issues in battles.
Voice acting is somewhat bad.
Needs more sidequests.

12853555.review:
First of all, the combat. The challenge tends to fluctuate between "Unnecessarily Difficult" to "Infeasibly Difficult" on the standard "Captain" setting. I suggest setting it to "Ensign" on your first playthough. Sunrider uses standard tactics-based combat: Move ships and ryders across a 2D plane, and use a variety of weapons and special abilities against the enemy fleet. Each unit has a distinct combination of weapons and abilities that make them suitable for special roles, and each weapon type has some kind of defensive counter. It's more than just rock-paper-scissors, however. Overcoming armor, shields, or flak involve different methods that will keep you on your toes. The enemy is smart, as well. They'll usually focus fire on two or three of your units at a time in order to take it out, and reinforcments seem endless at times. The animation on ships and ryders as they move and fire looks really great at first until you realize that they're a bunch of stop-motion still images of more complex 3D models. Overall, the combat is about average. Good, but not great, and way more challenging then it needs to be at times.

Sunrider's strong point is it's story, which turns out to be surprisingly profound. At first glimpse, it would appear to be a kind of harem anime that occasionally breaks out in space combat. Depending on your personal inclination, this could be eather painfully annoying or downright F*cking Awesome. That's about half of my recommendation right there. The characters are bright and colorful without becoming annoying (for anime characters, anyway). Despite most of the cast being in love with the male antagonist to varying degrees, the game plays it straight and doesn't let the romantic tension get in the way of the larger story. It's vaguely reminiscent of Fire Emblem: Path of Radience in that you play as a single captain/commander of a small team of effectively mercenaries fighting against a massively overpowering army/fleet that conquered your homeland/world. But don't let that fool you into thinking that the decisions you have to make are going to be so cut and dry. This game is perhaps the only one that does a morality system properly: 

There are no gauges, only consequences.

Do you rescue the captued people from being sold into slavery by a minor band of pirates, or do you assault a vital enemy resupply base while it's vulnerable? Do you rescue a team of diplomats from being executed, or do you leave them to their fates so that their empire will declare war on your enemy? There is no wrong answer, only the one you didn't pick. Whatever you choose, there will be consequences of your actions. And you will face them. No matter how obvious the "right" answer seems to be, the game will be right there, raising an eyebrow at you and saying "...Really? That's what you're going to do? Well, alright then..."

Can you sleep at night with the image of a civilian liner exploding under heavy fire? Of a little girl with a hole in her chest? Of a valued crewmate having her arm blown off? 

Brace yourself, Captain, because this journey isn't going to be easy. Righteous intentions don't always mean positive results, and no good deed goes unpunished.

12818077.review:
Alors voilà, je me lance dans la critique de cette petite perle...

(Sautez à la conclusion si vous voulez un avis direct, sinon, bonne lecture de mon looooong commentaire.)

Par quoi commencer ? J'ai du mal à y trouver des points négatifs.
Ah oui, la bande original, que je qualifie sans détour d'absolment sublime, la conception artistique dont certains diront qu'elle manque de finesse mais que je trouve parfaitement bien réussie. Oui oui, les vaiseeaux et les ryders ont l'air un peu old school je dirais, mais le tout est d'une cohérence tout bonnement superbe.

Les personnages sont plus qu'attachants (à noter que l'équipage est constitué à 95% de femmes, à croire que Kayto est le seul homme à bord du Sunrider...), l'histoire bien que quelque peu classique, se suit avec plaisir.

Les dialogues (en anglais, ok) souvent très savoureux donnent des situations des plus hilarantes.

Alors oui, pas de honte à l'avouer, un tactical rpg space opera sur lequel j'ai carrément craqué, un coup de coeur à 100%. Je me dois quand-même de reconnaître que la vidéo d'intro m'a non seulement surpris mais m'a surtout fait me demander sur quoi j'étais tombé... Idée très vite chassée par la qualité irréprochable de ce "petit jeu" sans prétentions.

Côté gameplay, de la difficulté pouvant aller de simplissime à tout bonnement écrasante en passant par parfaitement équilibrée, un système de R&D tentaculaire et extrêmement bien pensé (prenez-en de la graine, pseudo space-opéras se prétendant révolutionnaires par leur systèmes de recherches se voulant exemplaires).

Je déplore pourtant un peu le faible nombre de missions annexes.
Et à ceux qui diront "pouah, c'est que des planches 2D, ça craint", les mecs, si vous regardez votre écran par le côté, il est plat aussi. Alors au diable les standards de ce monde du jeu vidéo se voulant toujours plus  "éblouissant" et "bling bling". A bon entendeur.

En bref :
Un jeu que tout amateur de space opera et de manga se doit de terminer, et de reterminer sans modération.
Une petite pièce sans prétention qui se révèle être à mon sens un chef-d'oeuvre dans lequel les créateurs se sont donnés à fond (en passant, si les développeurs me lisent, bravo messieurs-dames, j'adore.) sans prétendre à quelque réussite que ce soit. 
Cela fait longtemps qu'un jeu vidéo n'a pas suscité autant en moi (depuis baten kaitos origins, c'est vous dire, et pourtant j'en ai fait, de tous les genres, de toutes les couleurs, de toutes les prétendues orientations). Alors arrêtez de toujours vouloir donner de la façade, vos jeux on ne leur demande qu'une histoire qui nous prend, de la durée de vie, et une conception artistique et sonore qui nous transporte.

Pour conclure, je dirai que ce petit jeu gratuit met une sacrée claque dans la face à tout ce qui peut sortir de plus high tech et de plus cher (ça va de paire) en revenant aux essentiels et en charmant, en passionnant, en enflammant parfois (oui, oui) le joueur.

Bravo, oui bravo. Je suis conquis.
A quand la suite ?

12782208.review:
I normally don't write out reviews (and I'm sure it'll show) but I cannot leave this game to go onto other without trying to get others to see if they'd like to experience what I did. So here it goes, ahem....

Sunrider is a storybook game with simplistic strategy elements, if you've ever wanted to play out a Space Mecha Anime now's your chance.

The story is the highpoint of the game. Taking you from one point to another as the captain of a new starship that's been expelled from its homeland. The plots twists and turns between the moral dilemmas you must navigate. Do you stop the slave traders whole will be vulnerable for a limited amount of time and free innocents? Or do you attack an outpost of the enemy that attacked your home world that will be ripe for an assault before the relief fleet can arrive? This is one of many choices you will have to make, weighing in your fight against the enemy, the morality of your choices, and how your crew may become enraptured or disillusioned in the struggle based on the decisions you make. This makes them hard to make and that's a good thing.

The characters are one dimensional at first, fitting into their respective tropes and cliches. You've got the by-the-books First Officer, the ditzy and childish ace pilot, the shy and reclusive tech genious, and so on. Over time though the characters grow and overcome their mistakes and past demons. I personally found myself looking forward to each chapter to not only see where the story was going (and believe me it hits you hard at times) but how the characters would react to it. It really brought a new dimension to the game that I found extraordinary for the FTP indie game.

The gameplay when it comes to space combat is simple at first: you have weapons and defenses, some are better at taking out certain units than others and so on. With every new chapter you get introduced to a new element added into the gameplay; new weapons, defense systems, units, scenarios, and an ever increasing (to the point of classic Nintendo level frustration at times) keep the combat relatively fresh and interesting. I will have to say that I found it to be the weakest factor of the game, due to lag in the combat system itself (though Python isn't known for being the smoothest of code when run, it's still a factor) and the voice work, while not bad at all for semi-professional or amateur work can become repetitive due to the repetitive nature of the gameplay. 

Last thing I want to mention is the soundtrack. It's gorgeous. I don't know of another way to put it. Each track fits the scene you need. Is the game trying to stress the struggle in life and death combat? Here's a score that gets your blood flowing. Need to make it a solemn and tormenting moment within the ever cracking psyche of a character? Have a eery and sorrowful piano arrangement. Need to emphasize just how ridiculous and lighthearted a scene is when your perverted doctor tries to give one of her "exams" to your character? Welp here's something to draws you out of the first 2 and into the new scene. It's a stellar job and a soundtrack I'll listen to outside of the game.

Overall it's a stellar game for a FTP and an unexpected jewel that I'm glad I found. The artwork is gorgeous and really fits the space opera/mecha feel it's got going for it. It'd recommend this to anyone fans of these themes and to those who enjoy a good sci-fi story with a range of silly and dark topics.

WARNING: There are a few scenes that are adult themed, and while they're few and far in between they might put some people off (though the fact that there's war an genocide is totally nothing to worry about /s)

9/10 would bang my keyboard in frustration at the combat and have the story force me to feel such potent feels again.

12752761.review:
Confused and lost and not sure what it wants to be.

That sums it up in a nutshell.

On the one hand, you got your "Sim-dateish" stuff that is a harem of girls to talk and romance with whilst the story progresses (i'll get to the story later) it sadly enough lacks anything interesting about them that most fully covered sim-date games usually have and stereotype galore all over the place (the shy engineer nerd, the bravado melee, the "happy heroic" hidden past girl, the perverted lady, the military girl of strictness and old LI, the out of place out of time girl and another military girl though she actually was the most normal and interesting of them all). 
It lacks any decency to keep track of status on what girl thinks what of you and though some enjoy it like this it however forces a ton of Save/Loading to see what does what instead of having a nice treebuild to follow what answer branches off where so you can backtrack easier and dont have the hassle of Save/Loading a ton to see all the different endings/scenes. Yet again I have to mention some like it, I however dont and I am pretty sure a lot of others do not as well.

Then we get to the story, predictable to a T and straight forward with barely any branching of. 
Though i'll admit one tiny twist caught me of guard (and I felt stupid) afterwards its easily noted what is going on and what will happen over the course of the game. It however is well presented and I enjoyed the first half immense (episode 1 I believe) yet was rather dissapointed with the end of the second half (episode 2) and was left behind with the "That it?" feel. It also did not help that for some reason the attention given to the crew in Ep1 suddenly fizzled away in Ep2 giving me reason to care even less for the rest of the crew besides my picked romanced girl, this pretty much also killed my will to replay the game multiple times for different romancing.

Then the gameplay, it starts of rather well actually a decent few fights with a good mix of challenge on normal/captain difficulty and for a moment its even fun to adjust and upgrade your ship and ryders. 
Then however (if you wish to continues to play on those difficulties) it takes a rapid nosedive downward. The UI/HuD for the TBS part of the game is dreadfully annoying more often then not which becomes more and more frustrating as the game suddenly decides to fling a TON of ships at your face expecting that you min maxed every single part of your ryders/ship in order to get by.
This takes away the fun fact of how you wish to build/upgrade your little battle group and more or less forces you to tackle it -that- way or no way at all. It sure as heck bumbed me down and when frustration was maxed I just went "FUCK IT" and lowered it all the way down and blazed to the rest of TBS part of the game. This sure did not help keeping my mood up for the story as well and created even more detachment of the characters.

Then the question remains, recommend or no? 

Well, first of, its free and thus there really is no reason to at the least try the game out once. Play it for a battle or 2 and see if the story hits. If it doesnt then just carry on.
However if you enjoy visual novels with a side dish of gameplay then this game at the least will keep you entertained for its brief few hours of life it has.
It however is no Princess Waltz (for the ones who know it, pervs) or Karawa Shoujo (Check it out if you havent, its good and its free! Google the name if you want to find it though, i'm lazy) and needs a lot of improvement before becoming even something close to that. 

Thus I give this a 5 out of 10 with its saving grace that its free, would this be costing cash (even if it had been tiny amount) i'd prolly have said to let this slide and be forgotten.

12747629.review:
Easily one of my favorite visual novels.  This game is for the VN officionado who is looking for a little something "more".  Sunrider offers difficult, gripping decisions that will test your willpower.  Primarily, who will be my waifu!?  There is a host of female characters for you to douse your loneliness with and they go beyond the typical harem tropes.  You know, the tsundere, the tomboy, the A-Cup Angst, the cute girl with no emotion except that one time when she opened up but is still oblivious to the world around her, the insecure bashful one, the one who WANTS YOU NOW, the super peppy one, and so on.  

While these tropes are in the game the fact that you rely on them in battle helps give them personality.  Each of your potential waifus pilots a ryder (essentially a gundam) and you have to build their stats appropriately to fit them into your battle scheme.  That's where the fun of this game is.  The combat in the game is great!  I found a lot of fun in building my ryders and testing their metal in glorious combat.

But being a commander in charge of the fate of the universe is stressful.  That's why all successful star commanders know that you can't save the universe without a host of females to support you.  A man is as only as good as his choice in romance options!  But, alas, with so many waifu's and so little sexual stamina that's just one more obstacle for you to overcome.  

This game doesn't hold your hand, but your potential waifu will.

12703690.review:
Short review:

Fantastic game. If you've ever been a fan of either tactical strategy games or visual novels, Sunrider is for you.


Full review:

As a long time fan of both visual novels and strategy games, I found Sunrider to contain the best elements of both.

The strategic fleet management system eschews traditional RPG "leveling up" in favor of cash-based upgrades for your ships that can be partially refunded and reallocated. All of your potential to create success in the missions begins with how you spend your cash, so spend wisely and plan your upgrades around what you want your team to accomplish.

Once you enter the fray, you'll find a tactical battle system that is, in a word, challenging. At normal (or "Captain") difficulty, even as a 25 year veteran of strategic and tactical gaming, there were several missions that had me pulling my hair out as my comrades were annihilated one after another by the unrelenting tide of foes. But that made the satisfaction of eventually conquering those missions all the higher, and if you want a more casual experience or are only playing for the story, don't let the battles frighten you. Many easier levels of difficulty are available, including one that makes the battles a mere formality so that you can get on with the story.

And you'll want to get on with the story, as it is surprisingly deep and exists in a beautiful area of moral uncertainty that few games tackle as successfully. There are choices to make that will leave you feeling like Sunrider isn't just a game; in a game, the hero should always be able to do the obvious right things, save every princess, and slay every dragon. But in Sunrider, you may have to choose between the princess and the kingdom, knowing you can never rescue both. You may even be surprised to realize that the dragon isn't necessarily the villain. In that sense, Sunrider recalls the best moments of morally ambiguous visual novels like G-Senjou no Maou. It will make you question the nature of good and evil.

The obviously limited budget and tiny development crew would be easy to cite as drawbacks, but in my view they benefit Sunrider enormously. I can imagine many ways that throwing better graphics or higher production values at the game would just detract from its tactical and storytelling heart. The simple anime-style artwork serves its purpose and effectively connects the player to the mostly-likeable characters. If there's anything negative to say, it would be that the voice work of the combat lines doesn't add much to the game given the high amounts of repetition. I would have instead preferred to see voicework in the actual dialogue segments between fights.

It comes down to this: If you have ever had space in your heart (no pun intended) for story driven tactical strategy, play this game. You won't be disappointed, and it will cost you nothing but a little of your time.

Or a lot of your time.

12702507.review:
I was coming into this expecting something much less than what it was. Gosh, was I fooled.

This game is in dire need of optimization and further patches - it can chug worse than a Prius trying to haul a mobile home. The UI doesn't register your clicks sometimes, and the save / load screen could use some work as well. The battles can be 'Nintendo Hard' to the point where if you don't optimize your ships a certain way, you will not survive.

But, it is FREE - and for some great space battle thrills, and a hard hitting story - Sunrider has definately earned the hours that I've poured into this game. The usual anime tropes and character archetypes show up here, right down to hearing 'I'm not doing this because I like you' in the middle of a firefight, and not only that - but a few raunchy scenes make their way into this release. Thankfully, while at the end of the day this is still a japanese style VN - the game isn't overloaded with these moments, and doesn't seek to be a hentai.

The story combines perfectly with the fighting, almost every mission feels like a fight for your life while being hunted by a fleet far superior to your single capital ship, and a few brave allies in their 'Ryders'.

By the time I saved the Agamemnon, I felt like a hero with a cause.

Tl;dr

FOR YOU IF:

- You have a fondness for grid based space battle games (ex: Super Robot Taisen Series)
- You enjoy japanese style visual novel series backed up by decent characters, a great story, and deep music

NOT FOR YOU IF:

- You are phobic towards the usual anime tropes verging on the NC-17 level
- You hate hard games and you are too stubborn to use the difficulty settings

Grab your naval uniform and your best cologne: it's time for an adventure.

Sunrider is an excellent, challenging tactical RPG with a good mix of humor, drama, moral choice, and waifu. The player character is the extra-sparkly Captain KAYTO SHIELDS, a living aphrodisiac who attracts a mix of multitalented women to help him take down an improbably powerful terrorist organization.

Filled with mecha, explosions, and surprisingly deep moral choices, Sunrider is definitely worth the time to play. Thus far, two out of three sections of the story have been released, with the third and final installment due to be released in early 2015.

12651540.review:
Alright. The story is nice, the characters have actual dimensions and interact with each other, and it can be a very human portrayal.

But! And there is a but, the combat can be described as 'maddening'. I got to a late-game section, admittedly with screwups, and hit a stone wall even on Normal. Some of the side missions are past completing in terms of ability, and even further than that you won't know until about twenty minutes into a couple that since you didn't knock out A mech/ship so quickly you wind up not being able to do a damn thing about it when you lose. Also? A strategy to warp should involve the fall-back warp BACK. A strategy they teach in-game is a sure-fire way to get your ship down to half health or less in a single turn.

The visual novel? Written well. A few mistakes here and there, but interesting. The combat? Anything above Ensign (mid-level, basically) you may as well go grab a brick and start smacking yourself in the head with it.

Also? Was kinda hoping there to actually BE romance. Not just pining. Ending's a bit abrupt as well.

I've played 1-2 VN's in the past and was never thrilled with the result, but I really did enjoy Sunrider. The story, while overly cliche in the beginning, really grows into something magnificent. Couple that with a beautiful soundtrack and fun space-based, turn-based strategy battles (I'm not a whole fan of the turn-based strategy genre, either, but Sunrider makes them entertaining), and this was one of the biggest surprises in all the time I've spent gaming. I'm not a big fan of the turn-based strategy genre, either, but in Sunrider I was always looking forward to the next fight. I hope they do make a sequel. 

I would recommend this game. I have recommended this game. Get this game. It's free.

12619220.review:
A very satisfying game, that falls just short of great.  There's a lot of things I really love about this title, and then it introduces something that makes me say "...so close."  Take the combat for example:  it's tight, engaging, there's enough diversity and a bit of room to explore...but it could be so much more.  A few more side missions; the chance to recruit a few other pilots; maybe some mechs that are choice based unlockables.  You can do a lot here, fairly easily and what you do get is nice...but it could better.

The story's the same way.  It's moving and interesting and it presents a lot of pressing moments...but then it makes some half-hearted attempt at humor and all I can do is cringe.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed this game and I'd recommend it to anyone who can look past the dating sim exterior, but it could have been a solid, all-around title with broad spectrum mass appeal.  As it is, it's a great Srpg and VN game, but if you can't look past the harem theme extior, it's probably not for you.

12618043.review:
The Visual Novel part of this game is highly enjoyable. Storyline is great, characters are interesting. Some jokes made me wholeheartedly laugh. Design of the characters and backgrounds are nice. There is no voice acting (for the Visual Novel part), but I don't think it would bring much anyway. As for the soundtrack, it probably is what got me hooked onto playing this game nonstop for 2 days. You just don't make a good visual novel without nice BGM.

However, when it comes to the tactical turn based combat part...
Well, this game has been made with Ren'py. Basically, that means it's been coded in good ol' python. As a result, it requires quite a beast to run. My computer is not brand new, but I still run most of my games in ultra without any frame rate drops ; In Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius, there's an animation played each time a unit lands an attack and hell, it was ugly-laggy for me.
Little thing that also bugged me is that I felt like I didn't know everything about the combat system (which weapon is effective against which protection, what kind of weapons has the ennemy vessel equiped, what were my objectives for that mission again ? et caetera).
Basically, those issues could be fixed by adding a little more explanations about how the combat part works and the option to automatically skip fighting animations. Truly not much.

In the end, I'd say this game was a great experience for me. Issues explained right above made the combat part pretty crappy for me but hell, I was there for the visual novel part ! And considering it was a free, indie project, I've been surprised by its quality. 
So yeah, if you're looking for a strategy game, better have a beast computer or search somewhere else. If you're into visual novels, just go for it, it's well-made and 100% free.
Game was a bit short (16h for me, without any rushing it), but the sequel is already announced, I'm definitely looking forward to it !

12616685.review:
It's an interesting game and It certainly looks nice.

Basically, your "character" is a space warship. You can upgrade its statistic just like you would attributes of your hero. You gain "experiences" in combat, which you can use for special abilities, again in combat.
Your ship, and all of the other ships in your/enemy fleet have special abilities or attacks. This allows greater tactical (turn-based) combat. The combat could be very enjoyable if it wasn't for one huge problem...

The problem is, that there is just too much "animations" in the combat, which is extremely boring and a whole lot more annoying. This brings the game down really fast and I just couldn't stand it. You can cut the animations short by clicking, so you will click more than you would in Diablo, and still you will wait a lot because of ... reasons I guess? 

Same goes for the dialogues. There is a lot of them, and unfortunately they are unnecessary and uninteresting, which gets really annoying really fast.

So, I can recommend this game because it's free, and maybe if you have more patience you can delve deeper than I did. I certainly see the appeal, it's just not a game for me.

12602693.review:
Sunrider is a marriage between the visual novel genre (of the dating sim kind) and turn-based tactics.  Is it any good?  

Well... it depends on what you're looking for.

The combat side of things is solid, if a bit too challenging.  You will struggle in the early missions because you don't have money to actually upgrade your stuff yet, and later missions will probably have you restarting a battle a couple of times (I'm looking at you, Legion Battle).  Also because the limited amount of money, you can easily cripple yourself by upgrading less-than-optimally.  However, your hardwork will be rewarded by that pride you feel when you triumph against nigh-impossible odds.

The visual novel side is where I think could use some work.  The story itself is pretty standard space opera and the characters hit all of the tropes associated with their archetypes.  That doesn't mean that it's poorly written; there are some pretty powerful moments in the story and I don't mind the space opera plot, but I wish they play around with the character a bit.  Make them less of cardboard cutouts of anime girls and more fleshed out.  As it is, the characters don't really stand out from others in the genre.  Still, this also means that if you like the characters in most other visual novels, you will like them just fine.

So it seems that Sunrider is better suited as a tactics game than a visual novel.  But I think the fusion between the two means that there's something for fans of either genre here.  It's an uninspired game, but a solid entry nonetheless.

12591594.review:
My first venture into the Visual Novel category. Technically, it's half VN/half turn-based tactics. This was a big point as I figured the most similar game I've played previously was Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance. Between that and my familiarity with the Phoenix Wright games, I figured I was prepared for the type of story I was going to get.

I was not prepared.

Maybe my first clue should have been the all female cast on the promo screen, or the characters alternating between school girl outfits (on a battleship?) and Evangelion-style jumpsuits. I quickly realized I'm probably sufficiently older than the target demographic for this game.

You play as the last good guy in the universe, apparently. Every other male character onscreen is the enemy, or at least kept arms-distance away from the plot. You DO get to interact with many young women, several of whom are pining for you to some degree. I was expecting Phoenix Wright and instead got Fate/Stay Night. There should be a distinction for Visual Romance Novel, because it's about as self-serving. Oh and there's space politics.

To be fair, the dialogue does discuss plot elements of some moral ambiguity, and does give reasonable choices in the same regard. Though since I haven't finished the game I don't know how those choices play out. The overarching story has a lot in common with the aforementioned Fire Emblem game (remnants of a conquered land seek to stop the invading army from unlocking an ancient power by requesting the aid of the other superpower, and there's a princess) but is played here with more nuance. The benefit of VN format, I guess.

The tactics maps are the top reason I keep playing. They are challenging without feeling unbalanced on the default setting. The music's pretty awesome, too.

Overall, this game is pretty middle-of-the-road. It didn't persuade me to the VN genre, and doesn't offer enough that I could recommend it to someone who doesn't already seek it out. I don't think it's bad, it's just not for me.

12534827.review:
This is simply the best Original English language visual novel made as of yet. The characters are likable, the story is a proper story with actual conflict and character development. The combat system is good, though the animations can get a bit tedious at times. You can turn the fights into visual novel mode if combat isn't your thing... The biggest issue with visual novel mode is that, well, you still have to do the fights. I also wish that your choices had more impact on the actual game. Although the game seemed to care about which choices I made in First Arrival, I don't think they really had too much of an impact on the story. But, maybe your choices in this game will impact the next a little bit more.

The people at Love in Space are brilliant, and I can't wait for the next chapter to come out! I'm sure that if you seemed interested enough to read this review, you will absolutely adore this game, just as I did.

Also, thanks to Sekai Project, who published this game on Steam... Look forward to the games they are going to be releasing too! If you liked Sunrider, I'm sure you'll like the other Visual Novels coming up.

By the way, I noticed the Fault reference in game... Nice to see that AID has seemingly managed to make a series that could span however far into the future Sunrider is set!

12534788.review:
I came across this while browsing Visual Novels with a Turn-Based-Tactics/Strategy RPG element, and I was quite surprised that there was one of western making. 
While intrigued, I was a little apprehensive at first as to whether this could be made to work, but the story was well written overall and had few hangups or inconsistencies, which is a rare enough sight to warrant praise. Generally, modeling it on japanese, or rather VN-specific storytelling conventions went over well, without these elements seeming out of place. It doesn't stick slavishly to them, however, and thus avoids a few frustrations common to many japanese works, like the Hero or other characters being near-imbecile and choices not being able to counteract that. 
The story itself, aside from being a hybrid of two storytelling traditions, is quite dramatic and with many twists that one often doesn't see coming in quite that way. The finale of the second episode and the contents of the reveal alluded to in the title was in itself not too surprising, for example - a few things about it were foreshadowed - but it still managed to play my expectations in a way that my guesses were off. With only one playthrough, I can not clearly say which of the character scenes are specific to routes or what seperates a route from another, which was a bit odd, being used to the often fairly ooc handling of this matter in japanese VNs. Since this didn't detract from the story or introduce inconsistencies, it isn't truly a criticism, and fits the narrative of the captain being focused on his work more than romantics as well. 
However, this relates to a general feeling that there is little feedback. On the story side, this may actually be worthy of praise, as I could honestly not tell whether or if some of my choices impacted the flow of events, or in what way. There were still some scenes that seemed to relate to my decision tendencies in the past apparently unconnected to choices, and there was only one situation where I had a feeling of redundancy, so it may have been a deliberate decision. The one event where something felt redundant was (as far as I can tell) on the Chigara route, where she tells Shields about Asaga behaving odd, and Asaga shows up to do just that. But following that, the next conversation pause has a conversation about that matter with Asaga, which does not seem to entirely reflect that Shields met her shortly before. Given that there was a pitched battle inbetween, it does not seem inconsistent, but still serves as an example for the ambiguousity of the choices and their influence that I regularly observed. 
The relative lack of feedback compared to other VNs I have played may exist in the story, but does not create a negative impression there, however, it contributes greatly to the "gameplay" side being frustrating in places. I should note that I played the game on normal difficulty, as is recommended. Why so, if I was frustrated by some of the battles? It is my personal opinion that a game should to some extent frustrate, and the frustration may be used to further the storytelling. This possibility was used here, and very effectibely so. However, this doesn't change the fact of the frustration itself. Indeed, I resorted to safe scumming and sometimes spent over an hour on a battle, particularly at Ongress, where I can not even say how many hours I spent on trying to make it work. In the end, I rolled back to before the pleasantly long "optional" portion of three missions and solved all of them. Before, one of them seemed too difficult and I chose to skip it, but it turned out that I very much needed the money, and after being battered at Ongress, it was suddenly a quite tolerable level of difficulty. I feared this level of frustration - which was detracting from my enjoyment, because it seemed to keep me from progressing with the story - would persist, as the odds climbed ever higher in the war. There was no true relief, something I connect with japanese VNs more, where there usually are a few easier battles (or perhaps, grinding opportunities) after a high-stakes, pitched bout. The next optional mission also was a headscratcher, though the fact was reflected in the character comments in a pleasantly amusing way. At that point, I felt reminded of the puzzle missions of Super Robot Wars J, where there is precisely one way to solve the situation, more than a relatively free-form TBS game with an upgrade mechanic. This turned out to be a passing spell, because the final battles following shortly thereafter were comparatively easy, not least because I now knew hiring both Alliance Cruisers and all Four Union Frigates was virtually required.
The upgrade mechanic in general seems like a money sink, because the influence of the upgrades is very incremental and the prices are staggering, considering the tight finances resulting from there being no easy battles, and not many optional missions - six, unless I they are missable, and the first two are mutually exclusive. After rolling back to have a fighting chance at Ongress and reworking my entire upgrading strategy, I skipped many upgrades in favor of the Mercenaries and some of the Mining Union offers, and the performance of my units largely didn't change, regardless of whether they had the upgrades or not. The effect of upgrades is also very inconsistent - upgrading damage, for example, only translates into an increased performance after a lot of money is invested into that single unit, and as I noticed with the mercenaries, having more damage dealers is more cost-effective than having a single more powerful Ryder, with some exceptions. Upgrading Flak or Shields, meanwhile, has a direct and noticable effect because it shifts the targetting priorities of the enemy, and upgrading hitpoints is necessary to survive in formation once those priorities are shifted. 
Therefore, while it seems that a very incremental and spread-out upgrade system would give the player great control over the performance and specialization of their units, the cost factor and the limited effects of some upgrades make very few upgrade plans truly viable, and the en-block upgrades bought from the Union are generally more cost-effective, even though some of them are consumables. This may be subject to change, since the Upgrade system appears to have provisions for further development, and there was a mention of Ryder weapons being swappable in the beginning which never materialized, though I found the fixed specializations entertaining. However, some Ryders are extremely situation-specifc, like the Ryder-killer Phoenix, which can do almost nothing else and doesn't kill fast enough to be truly effective. 
Those hard mechanics are what contributes most to the battle frustration, but a few changes there would help much. For example, merging the four upgrade stats per weapon into two, linking defensive stats to offensive in single upgrade, making energy more available and thus quality more useful compared to quantity, but this of course requires a lot of balancing.
Any criticism I could direct at the storytelling is much less clear-cut and would set me above the very tight wordcount limit these reviews are subjected to, but that and the characters are generally the strength of the game, while the combat aspect would need some more work - particularly, I found the balance between these two elements better in the first episode, since the optional battles in the second are the only ones without witheringly high stakes, which is exhausting after a while. It bears to hope that the next episode will introduce some more chaos intead of a firmly climbing pressure, since the ending of this one leaves room for a less straightforward main story advancement.

12515444.review:
Review outdated and based on Act 1 exclusively: 

There's a decent and enjoyable game in here, but the strategy RPG half doesn't run well, and this is very curious for a visual novel not to run well on most computers.

I have a pretty high-end gaming rig and it still stuttered significantly. After sharing it with someone with a more average rig, they could barely run the game. You can always read it in Novel Mode, but it's not particularly long or worthwhile in that case. Characters are pretty archetypal and the general plot, aside from the diplomat rescue, isn't much to write home about right now.

The strategy gameplay is somewhat flawed and especially punishing, and late-game is especially brutal with insistence on missile spam that can wipe out most of your team quickly from most ranges. This is especially frustrating in levels requiring you to advance to the opposite side of the map as moving and attack draws from the same energy pool. It does adequately capture the sense of opposing an overwhelming force, but luck-based factors of missing are frequent and necessitate time-consuming save stating and reloading. It's challenging if this is up your boat, but it can easily frustrate in combination with the game engine's inefficiency.

There are definitely things I like a lot about this, mostly the attention paid to lore and background, and this is definitely a promising enough start to a potential series. The strategy RPG component must be optimized, however, as it is very difficult to enjoy at this point. Much of the story is spent setting up characters and the setting in general, and there is a lot of room to grow and make later episodes much more worthwhile. As a standalone game for now, there's much to be desired.

It is free, though. If you have a high-end rig, the strategy RPG should run good enough for you to enjoy. Otherwise, you should look elsewhere.

Storywriting. The characters are pretty good, I mean they have their tropes but that's to be expected somewhat in Anime. As long as they are unique in the end it's somewhat good. 12490468.review:
"Пришел чтобы посмеяться над анимашной космооперой, остался ради геймплея" (с.)
Игра представляет собой эдакий дейтинг-сим космооперу с возможностью изредка выбирать опции в диалогах и командовать группой кораблей и меха в пошаговом бою на гексагональном поле. Не обращайте внимания на жуткие клише в персонажах и сюжете, которые набраны из аниме типа Евы, Гандама и всяких космоопер, а так же плохенько нарисованных девушек - хотя, иногда текст в игре до того шаблонный что невольно становится смешно и даже хочется посопереживать персонажам. Можете даже проигнорировать особый "патч" который открывает немного эччи и добавляет пару пятен крови на той или иной картинке. Ну или нет. (смайл)

Самое главное в игре это бои и апгрейды своего маленького флота. Вы начинаете с некиим аналогом "Нормандии" и всего парочкой меха, а заканчиваете флотом с полудюжиной меха и десятком всяких наемников и временных союзников. Смело выбирайте сложность "Капитан" и наслаждайтесь тем, как игра надирает вам задницу. Чтобы победить необходимо разобраться в механике игры и типах повреждений, и способностях своих юнитов. Хотя по отдельности все эти вещи не очень сложные, вместе они создают довольно сложную и вдумчивую механику. Каждая миссия по своему уникальна. Игра очень требовательна к балансу между движением юнитов и огневой мощью. Просто избежать врага или все время защищаться позволит не всякая миссия, не всегда удастся и изображать из себя берсерка.

В плане апгрейдов прежде всего обращайте внимание на кинетическое оружие, которое является единственным способом борьбы с тяжелыми кораблями врага. Вложите деньги в уменьшение стоимости за выстрел чтобы давать 2+ выстрела, а так же его точность и урон; дополнительное здоровье и очки энергии (хотя бы до 120) тоже не помешают практически всем юнитам кроме, пожалуй, "Паладина". Лазерное оружие к сожалению довольно слабо, хотя имеет кой-какое применение если комбинировать его с фрегатами. Ракеты хороши только если отменить врагу ПВО. 
Так же обязательно увеличьте радиус энергощита "Либерти" до 2 гексов и его мощность - это превратит вражеских меха из опасных в просто немного назойливых. Это, и кучное построение где все юниты с ПВО ("Флак") могут прикрывать друг друга обезопасит вас от лазеров и ракет.

Еще одна вещь о которой стоит знать это так называемая механика "Ненависти" - чем больше врагов убил ваш юнит, тем выше у врага на него приоритет. Поэтому стоит поднять здоровье "Санрайдера" к концу игры до 2000 из-за его мега-орудия, и используйте оставшиеся очки энергии у всяких мелких меха на дострел врага, чтобы распределить урон по всем юнитам.

Игра была создана на деньги собранные на кикстартере, по-моему всего за 40 тысяч, и при этом абсолютно бесплатна для скачивания. Несмотря на клише и редкие баги и вылеты, геймплей действительно захватывает и она однозначно стоит внимания любого кто любит красивые меха, не равнодушен к сериалам типа Макросс/Ямато/Гандам, и готов раз за разом перезагружаться ища новую тактику чтобы выиграть зверски сложную миссию.

12486685.review: Awsome Visual Novel + Tight Turne Based Sci-Fi/Mecha strategy RECOMEND to ALL who likes Anime Mecha or Sci-fi

12485355.review:
WHAT IS IT?

Its a story driven visual anime novel. Most of the game is text supported by frozen snapshots showing mostly girls in uniform. The story itself is massive but shallow regarding plot and excution. Gameplay distributes into a)reading b)selecting a path c)unit progress d)combat

a) reading (story)
Let me say that my younger self (a former anime geek) would ve been absolutely THRILLED if this would have been available in my time. It has everything a young male teenager would want.....girls, mecha, me being the hero, nudity, big boobs. Several decades later my mature self remembers how this feels but I cannot ignore the holes and unrealistic behaviour as well as technological improbabilities. Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is nothing more then a fairy tale in space. How any of the main characters would end up in their positions (captain, commander, fighter pilots) keeping the childish views and behaviour is beyond me....still....its amusing if only for its nostalgic value and I cannot help but wonder if the hero will "get" the girl :) It took me about 2 days to play through and even tho I would rate this "book" a 4/10 it was entertaining and easy to read...nothing to wrap your head around but then....its free so theres nothing to complain about really.

b) selecting a path
The first couple hours start promising. After the tutorial mission you are presented with a galaxy chart offering different systems you can visit. Many places dont open up before you talk to various crewmembers. Theres a hint of side-missions which would enable farming and a distraction but in reality the available content is extremely limited and becomes non-existant after a few hours when all you do is to follow the main story. All in all the game "tries" to present multiple paths but in reality its as linear as it can get.

c) unit progress
You start out with your flagship and collect Ryders (mecha) throughout the story. Each unit is represented with its own arsenal and abilities (support, assault, anti-capital, anti-mecha) and statistics providing numerical values in combat. Kills in combat provide a bounty which goes into your treasury as well as command points which are pooled for extra actions during battle. You improve unit stats by allocating funds to certain areas with each improvement becoming more expensive. This system gives you the opportunity to "specilaize" your units but money is extremely tight with no means to generate "extra" income (like repeating missions or an "open" environment which enables you to farm) you are dependant on getting optimal results in battles (re-playing them until you get it right) and a good "build" (dont waste money on upgrades you dont really need). Enemy units also become more powerfull and battles are always stacked against you. This can be extremely frustrating and forced me to take breaks in between to regenerate my motivation.

d) combat
Turn-based, hexagonal battle map with 2-shot battle animations. The combat system WANTS to look intimidating and complex but it fails as strengths and weaknesses are obvious and easy to exploit. Defensive play tops offensive in almost every skirmish and important command decisions are out of your hand as they are woven into the story so you are left with mop-ups or survival scenarios while the critical things (warp out of harms way, fire a torpedo down the death stars chute.......errrrr....I mean fire your main cannon directily into the enemies flagship planet destroyer nozzle) are displayed in text form. Combat eventually becomes repetitive, boring and also annoying where I find myself wanting to be done with it in order to continue the story.



Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is advertised as an anime novel and thats what it is. Gameplay is extremely limited as everything centers around the story which takes you by the hand and forces you into a "tunnel" to avoid any problems and distractions. I found myself flipping through the pages (clicking space) and reading the dialoges only to groan in annoyance whenever a combat came up. All you do really is click through available NPCs (order doesnt matter much) in order to relive memories and see how the story evolves. As far as I can see there is ZERO replay-value without multiple endings and maybe 2 or 3 side missions in the whole "game".


Now this might read like a crushing review but to be honest....its not that bad :)

First of all its FREE so what do you lose except time? The story itself is typical anime with a single male hero surrounded by young girls of various character (shy, dominant, offensive, rule-loving, unsecure, horny). You follow this crew to observe how they bond, their inner thoughts and how they try to find their place in the world. Everything is tailored to obeying orders, doing the right thing and fullfilling/finding a greater destiny. The universe is threatened by an "evil" opponent and you represent the only force of "good" with forces around you which you are unsure about (is the Alliance a force of good or out after after their own goals?). Mecha-design and exotic weapons appeal to the inner geek and the scarcly clad anime girls (young, boobs, uniform, colorfull hair, anime eyes) are what the typcial hormone-driven male kid craves (well...I did when I was young /grin) and THEY ARE ALL INTO YOU.

Yep....among the "hero saves universe" story theres enough left to observe how you run after your old love while being harassed and stalked by every other female in the game.

Characters are well drawn (the female ones.....the males......yech) but its all frozen snapshots. You get TWO erotic ones in case thats important to you (probably a quota thing).



Its not much of a game but its entertaining. All in all I would rate it a 6/10

12469538.review:
[h1]Sunrider: First Arrival - Космическая TBS с RPG элементами.[/h1]

Минусы:
-сложность некоторых миссий сильно завышена
-не совсем удобная система ведения боя (после каждого действия большая череда анимаций, приходиться жать ЛКМ со скоростью 1000 кликов в секунду, в результате чего можно еще и пропустить сюжетную вставку)
-проскакивают пошлости

Плюсы:
+бесплатная
+шикарный сандтрек
+не плохой сюжет

12456049.review: For me it is caught between a 9 and a 10. This visual novel has a nice story. Interactive and free. I love how this game reminds me of other games with similiar use of tactics. Nonetheless I believe the BG, Characters, Voices, and Art did show amazing continuity with it. Although I admit there is some details but as far as I have seen. This game has a lot of good even great. Multiple endings some choices, and to be honest if you liked War of the Human Tanks, you will like this. Also if you played any of other recently available on Steam VNs as of late, you will find a nice mixture. This one actually kept me entertained and interested. Although I admit pork chops should die, seriously and that goblin midget with a mask needs to get kicked like a football. I'm loving the game. What I find amazing is that it is simple and yet it reminds of me many other sci-fi related games. This game has provided me much entertainment and I do recommend it. It's not high action paced but the animations and the voice acting is what sold me. How many have actually done that? I'm not talking about VA in the scenes although that would be a plus but cost, however when they fight you hear them. I found that through this game a nice gravity of choice between the reality of what you want to do and have to do. Personally the comical relief brought about through the characters in between also helps. Not always so doom and gloom but it shows that there is more on people's mind. The artwork is very decent, the ships animations on firing were nice, the dialogue seems to be great. Some scenes show emotion and even makes me want to hear their voice. It's this type of game I do like. It gives you more than enough but it's so close to perfect they tempt you. Even though the voice acting isn't done, and the scenes with dialogue could use some more action, I do believe this is a 9-10 out of 10 in my book. Well done!

12425192.review:
My Captain Shield was emotionally unstable yet I found myself with a satisfying ending. GG WM (Well Made). 5/5

^ and that is the tl;dr of my review.

Combat (Captain Mode) 5/5

Captain mode is the Normal mode for this game. Out of 2 playthroughs (twice thru the 1st arc, and once thru the second arc), I can say I had no great issues. The last fight in the 1st arc was a fun challenge. Gameplay changes quite a lot depending on your unit investments (you spend cash earnt from scrapping enemies on weapon damage, accuracy, energy usage, HP, EP, and more). I usually set up my ship to fire two rounds of kinetics per turn. In the second arc, there are two battles which will feel impossible (and will be if you don't have the support units for it). The 1st difficult fight (in the second arc) is one of the three side missions. Do the other two first to rack in the cash. Then you can beat this side mission with enough game knowledge. The second hard mission, is just that there are TOO MANY ENEMIES! I mean seriously, TOO MANY ENEMIES JUST TO AMBUSH ONE CARGO SHIP! I WANT TO KNOW WHAT IS IN THAT BLOODY SHIP! Honestly though, the combat is fun. There are also 6 difficulty options that you can change in game, so if you get stuck on a mission, you have an easy way out. Or if it's to easy for the master tactician, then you can go be a flippin' space whale.

Characters - 4.5/5

Potential Waifus are all great. If you aren't happy with any of them, ask for a refun- Oh wait, it's free. Free Waifu is good Waifu.
Seriously though, from justice loving, to perverted, to tsundere, to childhood friend, to shy, to patriot, and all the way to "I only live to fight"; You have a large variety of waifu candidates.

Story - 4.5/5

*Prologue Spoilers*

You're a Captain who's just minding your own business, testing out a prototype ship (welcome to Mass Effect, the VN. Comes with extra waifus), when the USSR invades. Nah, just kidding. It's just a lot of angry people being told that they should be angry at everything, and to vent that anger by shooting space lasers and rail guns at everything that isn't them. So, after a massive capital ship called Legion singlehandedly rips apart your local fleet, it then nukes your capital city. Obviously, you can either die fighting or live to fight another day, so you run for your mfern life. Then you gather allies (waifus) from all over the galaxy to smash the angry peasants that nuked your home. The story is enjoyable though. I enjoyed it.

Style - 5/5

Style? You have a kick-ass ship, space lasers, space whales? Huh? Anyway, you have your own robot-piloting, waifu army. These bad girls have lasers, rockets, rail guns, swords and sidearms. They also disable capital ships, snipe rocket frigates, and download enemy porn collections? Urgh, that stupid pervert. What I'm trying to say is that this game is great.



Since it's 100% free, get this awesome game.

Well after a couple play thoughs with the current game I figured I would put my two cents in.

Over all this VN has a enjoyable story, great artwork, and a epic OST. Those alone would make me sugjest trying this VN.

But its not without problems gameplay if you can even call it that is poorly balanced after the first chapter where they have the training wheels on, your suddenly forced into a game where the only way to progress is the use of a single tactic that you will have to use over and over unless you like seeing the game over screen alot.
Also while your given alot of freedom to upgrade your units its pointless because even as the dev has said themselves the only counter to some of the enemys that are spamed repeatedly is to put maximum levels of upgrades on a single unit crippling all your other units, forcing you to min/max even on all but the lowest difficulty.
That means in order to beat the game your either have to play on a diffiulty where the game basicly plays itself or your have to have prior knowlage of end game enemys from the moment you start up the game for the first time.

To sum it up boot up the game for a spin its worth a bit of time despite the negative tone about its gameplay, just dont expect a fun "game" experence in the combat missions.

12412087.review:
Cliche anime girls everywhere can be annoying, but if you're purely interested in the tactics, you can easily skim read/ skip past the terrible dialogue and get to the space battles. While there are lower difficulty levels, the default setting is quite brutal and will punish illogical investments and particularly faulty tactics. It plays a lot like a Super Robot Wars game, although there is not much animation and there are fewer, stronger enemies. The graphics are sufficient to get the job done though and the latest update now helpfully shows enemy flak and shield zones on the grid.

The game doesn't really explain the enemy AI, flak and shield coverage as you go along, so it's worth heading to the wiki for a combat overview as otherwise missiles and lasers can seem hopelessly unfair.  Also be aware that rockets purchased from the mining guild are 1 use only weapons, unlike hired extra ships which stay with your fleet until destroyed.

 The main plus point: it's a completely free space tactics game.

12397750.review:
Right, let's get the criticism's out of the way first:
The combat system is minimalistic at best and many people claim, unfair because only 1 type of weapon is worth a damn against larger ships and you have VERY limited sources of that weapon. But thankfully, the game lets you switch to a visual novel difficulty, which essentially enables god mode.

And the second criticism is more a consumer protection complaint, in that with a visual novel advertising romance options, it is expected for there to be sex scenes in it. There are none and only one scene showing nudity of any kind but like I said, it's a consumer protection complain so I don't mind. (Heard something about a decensor patch but that would mean I'd have to go through the combat again so probs not worth it, even with god mode)

3rd, why does the Ceran military uniform look like a school girl outfit?

But now, let's get onto the reason I'm recommending this, publicly, at the risk of my friends calling me a pervert.
The writing is actually pretty damn good.
This isn't a visual novel in which everything goes right and everyones happy if you win the turn based battles. This game is pretty dark when you get into it. You wind up seeing the stresses of command, the grey nature of war, the difficulty of separating your emotions with what's best for the crew, protecting the lives of people you've come to care about, heck even child prostitution and stuff like that.
The game portrays a universe in which everything has gone to hell and it does it really well.

So take my advice: Put the tissues away, turn the game to visual novel difficulty and play it purely for the story. Don't expect anything more than a good story and you won't be dissapointed.

Also, it's free, so what do you want?

12396385.review:
TL:DR> This is a VISUAL NOVEL that happens to have some strategic battle included.  Keeping that in mind, this is one of (if not THE) best visual novels I've read/played.  Loved it.

Okay... where to begin?

First... I read one of the reviews that said this was beta.  There's one typo I caught... and yes, the battles in regular mode (and above) can be hard.  HARD.  But... it's a visual novel with a game inside it... you can set the difficulty downwards if you need to.  So... I can't really say it's unbalanced... it's balanced for being a nut-kickingly difficult fight.  Unless, you know... you don't want to work that hard and you choose to set it easier... in which case it ranges from much more friendly all the way down to why-do-we-even-have-battles-if-they're-that-easy?

So it's not unbalanced... there's a type I caught... and... um... yeah.  That's it.  If this is beta, sign me up!

Now... this is, first and formost, a visual novel... meaning READING!  You has to do it!  If you don't like reading narrative, you will hate this game.  If you think you can just skip to the good parts... you will still hate this game.

If you're actually willing to read every line of text (and this is a looooong game... I spent 20 hours on my first playthrough) then you will probably dig this as much as I did.

Characters are shallow... but not two-dimensional... they grow, they expand, they have REASONS for being who and what they are.  You get to know them... and you get to like them.  Investment in this story is easy and rewarding.

Also: I'M FIRIN' MAH LAZORS!

Still laugh everytime I hear that.  Sorry... where was I?

Oh, yes... story.

Is it predictable?  Yes.  Don't expect some Lanister twist here, but at the same time it's not Lost where you'll be wondering what the heck REALLY happened.  It's a good, fundamentally anime story... with girls in skintight suits and giant mecha... love interests from all directions (but not the cheesy, "I'll just date you all" male fantasy wank you might expect to find after the relationships start peeking out from behind the curtains)... and it does all of these tropes and more justice.

Now for some reason, I got to play it for free.  I have NO idea what that's about, and if your milage varies, well... I can say I'd have happily paid for this in hindsight.  $5?  Absolutely.  $10?  Probably.  More than that?  Hmm... hard to say.  There's not a lot of branches here... and they usually loop back to the same place.  Most people won't find a reason to replay it.  But honestly... for a good evening's worth (or two) of anime fun?  It's good.  Really good.

Final rating: best VN I've read yet.  All teh thumbs up!

I initially loved everything about the concept of this game. Interactive novel? Sure. Sci-Fi setting? Absolutely. Turn-based tactical combat system with upgrades? It's like a dream come true. Great in theory, but poorly executed.

I slammed face first in a massive difficulty spike early in the game. Playing on normal, I went from clearing the maps with no challenge to facing non-stop failures. I tried everything I could think of, and I faced a mission so terribly unbalanced that it has all the hallmarks of being unbeatable. Reading through the forums, this is an issue that's been known since at least August and still hasn't been resolved. I have lost all interest in trying to progress past this and seeing the rest of the game, or of anything else from the developers. If they can't get the balance right on something right at the start, where does that leave me thinking about anything else they do? If you aren't going to try and make it a fun experience, why bother having it there at all?

C) the most of the choices actually feel hard to do. the story is so gripping that you actually feel responsible if you make a choice that accidently gets 600 kids killed. but it also makes you feel happy you made the right choice when consuling a crew member who is feeling down.
D) none of the crew is in instant love with you (except 1) which means you have to make the right choices inorder to get the relationship you want. i like this idea and i wish more visual novels with romance did this.
E) the battles are HARD. i mean by the gods i had times where i wanted to punch my computer. going all out does not work. it willonly get yo so far until your main ship is surrounded by battlecruisers and you can't do anything but die. i like it though because it makes me have to think everything through to the last detail.
All in all i give this game a 9/10. if it wasn't for the few flaws this would have been perfect but not everyone is perfect so i applaud the creators and i hope they relase more free pieces of art on steam.

Na sowas!?

Dieses Spiel ist eine interessante Mischung aus Anime-Storytelling und einem überraschend ausgefeilten (Weltraum)Strategiepart!
Die Story zieht sich leider manchmal etwas (meines Erachtens) aber wer sich einem Anime nach dem anderen angesehen hat - wird sich hier zu Hause fühlen. Für den Rest - einfach klicken bis der Arzt kommt!  ;)
Da ich das Spiel bis jetzt nur einmal am Stück durchgespielt hab - kann ich nicht genau sagen - ob die eine oder andere Entscheidung  meinerseits - entscheidend für den Storyverlauf war (bis vielleicht auf den einen oder anderen bösen Blick von einem süßen Animegirli!?)

so etwas wie "the wolf Amoung us" - oder Mass Effect sollte man aber nicht erwarten!!)
Der Strategiepart sollte die meisten überraschen - eine schöne rundenbasierte Hexfeldschlacht im Weltraum - Star- oder Panzergenral läßt grüßen - die Waffen und Einheitenvielfalt ist gut abgestimmt und erfordert Anfangs ein wenig Geschick sich zurecht zu finden! Zum Schluss kann ich nur sagen eine nette Abwechslung zu den Endlosspielen der heutigen Zeit - und dazu noch kostenlos!? Aber selbst wenn ein paar Fortsetzung für einen Obolus folgen - würde ich zumindest den einen oder anderen Euro investieren!
