I must say, this game is just amazing. Not many games make me think both inside and out of combat (and actually enjoy the thinking) but sunrider does a great job at that. They have you make decisions thought the game, some of which have you feeling so guilty as an rpg player.  Heres an example.

It contained the diplomat AND 600 children they decided to save.

As for actual combat I played on normal and so far its not too difficult but you'll see that a couple bad moves like having your stongest unit rushing ahead or even the squad as a whole can backfire and cost you the fight. also, events may happen in the middle of the fight making rethink your current plan, making it all the more interesting to play. overall I'd rate the gameplay a solid 8.0

The game doesnt take up much space so its a quick download so unless you're just not a fan of the genre or the type that only cares for gameplay alone, you should definitely give this game a try.

11282560.review:
I would not recommend this game. First, combat gets extremely tedious whenever the enemy has over 5 units, since you have to wait for each of them to individually move, fire, and see the results of the firing. And no, you can't just skip it. The HP and energy bars are unclear, so it's very hard to tell about how much health or energy a unit has at a glance.

However, the worst part is the character design. It is sexist, lazy, and insulting. All the women have the same body shape and face, despite being from different planets and regions of the galaxy. And the art looks too far finished for it to just be placeholders. And the pilot "uniforms" that the designers came up with are clearly impractical, and you can tell that they just took one of them and copied and pasted after changing the colors. They didn't even bother to erase their navels since the model they designed it after for some reason had a bare midriff. Also, it's plain insulting to assume the audience wouldn't notice the fact that 6 different mech pilots, how arrive on your ship at five seperate times, from various backgrounds, somehow have exactly the same outfit? Despite two of them being from different militaries, and by the way, it's extremely insulting to actual women military personal to put fictional military personal in those kinds of outfits.

TL;DR: Combat needs to be streamlined, and character art is sexist trash.

11268966.review:
This game has a number of issues you should consider, as they killed any appeal the game had for me before too long.

First, the characters and story are fairly bland, and many character's voices will annoy you easily, if not the first time, then after the tenth or hundredth time, and many of them are filled with meme phrases that personally annoyed me terribly.

Second, the actual gameplay.  While the gameplay works in the small-scale, when it attempts to have larger scale battles later on, it fails.  This is largely due to the ubiquitous use of missiles, which are extremely long-range, extremely accurate attacks meant to be rare and used sparingly.  However, in the later stages, the enemy spawns infinite reinforcements each with 4 or 5 missiles.  There is a stage in particular that is just boring and infuriating, because the moment you end your first turn, you WILL lose at least one unit to a barrage of more than a dozen missiles.  And unlike other attack animations, you cannot skip the missile's travel animation, leading to a wait of upto 10 seconds for each missile.  Having timed it, a turn for the enemies on a certain stage, skipping as many animations as possible, took two full minutes of sitting there watching missiles zoom across the screen.

Finally, the code needs polish. A lot of polish.  I am running an i7 processor and a GTX780, with plenty of RAM and an SSD, there is no reason for this performance.  In large battles, the animations become extremely choppy, and this happens when playing for extended periods as well. This also causes complete animation failures, and UI glitches, such as missiles never appearing, units not visibly moving, the commands menu disappearing, accuracy rates being displayed incorrectly or not being displayed at all, and unit buffs not being displayed.  While the game never crashed, it performed so poorly that when combined with these other issues just made the experience completely irredeemable.

To address the massive amount of attack spam, and long wait times between turns, a friend of mine has created a helpful guide to turn off animations. Manually.  The guide can be found here:   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=286831703

11241934.review:
I remember seeing the Kickstarter for this and liking the idea, though I was practically destitute at the time so I couldn't donate myself. I am glad to say that the LIS team has made some thing really special here. Its not without its flaws but this is an excellent sign for the quality of this series in particular and western VNs in general. Helps that its also a damn good turn based strategy game as well.

If I had to nitpick, the main antagonist, whom I refer to as Char on heroin, is overblown to the point of absurd humor even considering the classic mecha anime tone of the game's story. Where most of the characters are pretty well written I think he kind of stands out as a blatant and rather unamusing charactiture. The voice acting, which only exists in battle segments much like the confirmations of RTS units, is also hit and miss. Depends on your tolerance for US anime-dub quality voice work. Some voices are far better than others. 

The plot overall is entertaining, most characters are likable. The battles are actually very demanding, Ive heard of many people being forced to turn down the difficulty later on. I happen to like the mecha design, very reminiscent of Armored Core in many ways. The music is stunning, a highlight of the game. I found the character art a mixed bag, though nothing is so bad as to be distracting. There are severe frame rate issues in battles, but I am told this is being worked on and its not like TBS games require twitch reflexes anyway.

Overall highly recommended. If you like VNs, this is a promising story to follow. If you like TBS games there is a damn good one under the hood here, and maybe you can broaden your horizons with the VN elements.

Oh yeah, and it's free. Now we wait for the Space Whale DLC I keep hearing about.

REVIEW UPDATE FOR MASK OF ARCADIUS:

Starting off, I have a lot of great things to say about this second part of three, but first the bad. There are a number of memory leaks and other crashes in the new gameplay segments. I am sure these will be patched but I reccomend caution and liberal saving.

Now then, the good stuff. The game is challenging as ever, introducing new unit types to further ruin your day, like support mechs with debuffs and curses. This is a good thing, disregard the forum whining. Story is still engaging, with a lot of improvement in the characterization of Captain Shields and nice moments for the whole cast, even the antagonists.

Oh, and Char on Heroin is still hard to take seriously, so it's nice that the other two antagonists pick up his slack on the depth and likability department.

Frame Rate issues are still present, but massively improved from initial release. I still find this game running on open source VN software to be something of a miracle.

So yeah, heartily reccomend this second part of the game. I am actually anxious to see the third. Maybe we shall see one of those damn space whales, at last.

11239180.review:
Sunrider: first Arrival

Space? Check. Anime characters? Check. Mechs? CHECK!

Sunrider: first Arrival is a space based RPG where the player gets to command the Sunrider carrier ship and save the galaxy from the evil PACT, all with the help of some anime schoolgirls and their death dealing Mechs known as Ryders. 

Players get to make RPG-like morality based decisions such as save some civilians, or maybe kill them for a greater good. Of course the characters have their cliche ridden responses but this is acceptable and entertaining if anime drama is mildly interesting to you. The game soundtrack is suitably grand with a few different themes, but you may end up muting it after a while as the tracks are short and loop quickly. Voice acting is fairly limited as the story is told via text and visual effects.

The combat screen is where this game really shines. Units are presented on a grid, and each has a limited number of action points to spend on movement and attacks. Each offensive action triggers a brief anime style cut scene showing the unit making an attack as the crew member delivers a line of dialogue. There aren't many of these so they repeat frequently during a long battle, though who really gets tired of hearing 'Imma firing mah laser!'?

Fighting battles will be a fairly familiar process for players that are used to turn-based games, but the design of the interface often gets in the way of quick play - why have a unit only be selectable by clicking on a tiny area near it's middle? Or why have the weapon icons selectable only by clicking a tiny area somewhere above their middle? It's simply bad design that will infuriate you when it takes five attempts to get the game to register your click. Where are the shortcut keys? Why does the action skip over enemies' misses, but makes you click/space bar after they land a hit? Why are the unit health and action point bars so difficult to see and why oh why do they get covered over by a unit in the square below? Despite these issues the underlying combat is well designed, providing a strong challenge on normal difficulty. 

Winning a battle yields a reward based on your performance which you can spend to upgrade your carrier and Ryders' defensive and offensive abilities. The selection including upgrades to armour, action points, weapons damage and accuracy. Increasing your battle effectiveness and helping you progress through the game.

Sunrider would benefit from some polishing up, and no doubt the developers will do so in the future, especially if they wish to make a series of these games. Despite that it's engaging and fun to play, and as a Free to Play game is highly recommended.

11230991.review:
Do you have an interest in visual novels? If you do, then you owe it yourself to give [b]Sunrider: First Arrival[/b] a try. For a free, visual novel that's still in beta, this game is looking very promising.

The story, art, and characters are all well done, enjoyable and memorable. The turn-based battles involving the grid overview add a little more interactivity to the game as opposed to the standard [i]'read text and then make decisions'[/i] found in most typical visual novels. I enjoyed the game more for the story and the characters rather than for the turn-based battle system however, though the battles themselves were decently enjoyable up until the last few battles nearing the end of the game, where things began to get really tedious (and somewhat unforgiving). The fully voiced unit/character responses during the battle sequences are also a nice touch, and serve to give fights a more personal feeling, as characters begin to sound more desperate/concerned the more their ship's/ryder's health declines.

Those who wish to avoid or have no interest in the battle aspect of this game may be disappointed to know that there is currently no way to skip battles and just read through the game as a visual novel. However, there are difficulty settings which can make progressing through battles more rapid, or, if you're the type who really enjoys formulating strategies, much more difficult where every move must be carefully calculated in order to succeed.

Overall, [b]Sunrider: First Arrival[/b] is a title you may want to keep an eye on, as the game is already highly enjoyable and playable in its current state. There's drama, comedy, tragedy, and moral decisions to be found in the main story, and I found myself immersed in the plot so much to the point where I felt responsible for the decisions I had to make during the course of the game. Not only that, but I also felt that I actually cared about what happened to the characters; each of them have their distinct personalities and somehow manage to be endearing in their own ways...

Whether it's due to the epic soundtrack, the 'cutesy anime-style character drawings', the drama of the story, the turn-based battle system, or any combination of these, [b]Sunrider: First Arrival[/b] is a game that truly deserves your attention. It might not be completely polished (I experienced some kind of glitching or slowdown in many of the battle sequences), but for a game of this high quality to be made available completely for free is something I'd consider as a most welcome (and possibly unforgettable) gift.

[u]Play it:[/u]
- For the story.
- For the art, characters, and music.
- If you like or have an interest in anime.

[u]Don't play it:[/u]
- If you only want to play a polished, turn-based strategy game. (It's not bad, but you'll mostly be spending your time reading.)

11223261.review:
It’s very rare I write reviews but Sunrider deserves one. When I first seen this game I was sceptic, but since it was free to download I thought why not give it a go? I’m glad I did.

If I had to describe this game in two words it would be amazingly addictive. Out of all the games I’ve played over the past few years, this is without a doubt one of the best. It’s easy to pick up and challenging.

It’s a turn based strategy game set in the future. A bit like Gundam Wing, politics included. The storyline is second to none and the soundtrack compliments the game well, not to mention there are some good plot twists (even I didn’t see coming). You also get to make your own choices which make it a bit more personal and keep you involved. The Characters have interesting backstories and questionable personalises (in a good way). There is some adult humour involved (mostly with Doctor Claude Triello) but other than that it’s toned down innocently. 

I’m really looking forward to hearing more about this game and playing more. It would be nice if they continued it like the Mass Effect Series or even made a TV show. I would happily pay for Sunrider. The good news? it’s a free game so download and give it a try you won’t regret it.

All for one and one for all (Asaga Oakrun)

Marks out of ten? Over 9000

11223081.review:
A free VN that combines a space opera and a turn based strategy game, You play as a captain of a lone top of the line ship in your quest to fill your hangar with female mecha pilots. Sounds a little familiar? Galaxy Angel isn't too much different.  For a free game, it's not bad, it goes into some of the usual cliches, but otherwise manages to be entertaining. The combat isn't really explained to you but you'll pick it up quick enough, however it does seem a little wonky, your mechs aren't really able to fit their roles properly, and you'll just usually rely on your flagship to do any damage about 70% of the time.  The game is a little hard in that it takes you a llitle bit to actually find out what's effective, and focus on upgrading that while ignoring everything else, movement costs and certain upgrade prices probably need to be looked at.  Also the art is terrible. It's very bland and as far as character design goes uninspiring. For a game funded on kickstarter I'm pretty sure a better artist could have been obtained, Yes I understand there are a bunch of popular visual novels with less than stellar artwork, but they have more "heart" to them. At least galaxy angel had some style going on, in this the big bad guy is iron mask from F91 if he was a midget elf manlet, wadda fuk man.

The voice acting is tolerable.  The music choice is ill-fitting, super epic orchestral music should be saved for when it really matters, they should have taken a cue from homeworld and made it a bit more chill, hell the galaxy map music sounds like they almost ripped it from mass effect.


But hey, the game was free, and if you like space and mechs maybe you'll enjoy this game.

11219036.review:
The story is quite interesting, but so far it doesn't go any places you haven't seen before nor are there any big surprises in it, but it is fairly well written and it moves along at a good pace. It's biggest problem is that it is really the introduction of what is to come. So I will give the story a 7.

The character interaction is fairly classic romance comedy manga/anime however the story luckily doesn't linger long enough for the interaction to get "forced" in an attempt to obey the tropes, however this also means it doesn't linger long enough for the character to step outside this confine and develop to more unique characters. There is pretty much just one character we see any real development with, even though a few of the others seems ready to develop they fail to do so. So the interaction I will give a 6, its good but it doesn't lift the story any higher.

The combat are fairly straight forward but quite hard and a few of the missions are almost impossible, but on the up side it gives you a lot of option in what you want to do and how to expend your resources. For turned based combat it is actually really good at what it does, so I will give combat an 9.

The upgrade system is a bit of a mess frankly, while it is easy to see what you upgrae some iof the upgrades are meaningless in the increments they are in and otehrs are too expensive for the boost they do give. I feel this system needs a lot of adjusting or an overhaul, luckily you can "reclaim" all the money you spend to fiddle around with what works best. So since it still seems somewhat incomplete I will give it a 4.

The artwork is good, and to me seems very macross/robotech inspired for the msot parts the only thing that really got on my bad side was the use of "school uniform" outfit rather than uniforms or similar off duty clothes. So I will give this an 9.

The game itself can be unresponsive at times and be slow to react or because it is so slow to process where you click it makes you take an unintended action, this is very bad in the battles as these are really hard as they are already. So to play this game you need to saddle yourself with patience to make sure the game knows what you just pushed before moving on. Also the "target" places on the units you can select to affect with the action does not dictate if you select the right target rather their unit graphic (ryder or ship) does, this means a tall unit can partially cover for the above unit causing you to select the wrong one. Anyway I will give the "system" a 3, it is not unplayable, but it is very frustrating.

So overall I will give this game a 6, it has a lot of good qualities but a few glaring problems that in the current form needs to be fixed.

I have just finished this game and I have to admit that, as a long-standing fan of Visual Novels, this looks promising. I really liked the story and the setting overall, the characters were all-around great (with some obvious exceptions since the game is still not that long), and the relationships between them are well-made. But man, the BATTLES. I loved them now, I loved their tactical depth and I loved the fact that every battle seemed important for one reason or another. And the soundtrack is really great, I really loved "Sora no Senritsu", but the music was fitting in every moment, especially during battles.
There are still some problems, but they are mostly caused by the fact that this was more of an introduction: lack of side missions, plot still linear (the choices doesnt seem to affect much... for now), and some lag during battles. But all these problems will surely be resolved in the future games, so right now I'm looking forward to see more!

I've played my fair share of visual novels, dating sims, setting up a comedy club and things that should not be seen by younger players you name it. Sunrider: First Arrival is your typical visual novel where you find yourself in galactic civil war, commanding ships and mechs that is styled with a mixture of chess and battleships, ethical choices and attractive young pilots. Huh, thinking about it, guess it's not your typical visual novel. If you've played War of the Human tanks, conflicts are similar except turned based. Furthermore, it's free, everybody likes free stuff.

Pros:
+Mechs
+Engaging sci-fi conflict 
+Multiple and interesting heroines
+Fantastic VGM
+Ethical choices
+Challenging. Being outnumbered and out gunned.
+Free
+Bewbs

Cons:
-Short. To be honest, I was hoping for it to be longer but it's a tad short.
-Challenging. Being outnumbered and out gunned.


Note: I'm a little bias here as I'll love Visual Novels and anime. Also, if anyone has played visual novels like Koihime Musou, Sunrider is a futuristic version except, less women and less eroge. Furthermore, if you've played War of the Human tanks, battles scenarios are similar except turned based.

11199713.review:
UPDATED FOR MASK OF ARCADIUS: With the Part 2 update, the best free-to-play sci-fi strategy/visual novel hybrid game just got a WHOLE lot better! Mask of Arcadius not only adds the next chapter of the Sunrider chronicle, it also includes a slew of new content (new ship upgrades, new battle commands, recruitable mercenary ships) and a whole heap of changes and fixes that correct almost every issue I had with the game before. Most notably, the battle system has been changed from a square to a hexagonal grid, making battles that much more tactical (and the Vanguard Cannon has subsequently changed from firing directly forward to being aimable in any direction you want). More importantly, most of the little technical quibbles have vanished- there's no more lag, you won't have trouble clicking on the correct unit any more, accuracy projections now always work properly and tooltips have been added for all your weapons and abilities.

You're gonna need every one of these advantages, though, because the challenge level has spiked. Battles are much more stacked against you, with your forces regularly being outnumbered 3 to 1 or more. The enemy have received new units too and one of these, the PACT support ryder (an ewar unit that combines the debuff and healing abilities of both Chigara and Claude), will have you tearing your hair out. In actual fact, these last units somewhat detract from the game as they're honestly not very well balanced and can feel really cheap to fight against if you're playing on Captain difficulty or higher. The old issue of you potentially backing yourself into a corner if you don't buy the correct upgrades for your ship and ryders remains as well, with you needing to be practically psychic (or to have already played before) to know whether the next battle would require you to upgrade your flak or your shielding to weather the storm of the enemy's attacks. Regardless, the game will pose a real challenge even to hardened strategy buffs.

Story-wise, the plot is rapidly darkening. Serious moral choices continue to challenge your ethics (like the escort mission from part 1) in a manner that would test even veterans of Telltale Games (the planet of Ongess in particular gets incredibly dark). Even Cosette Cosmos, a character who in chapter 1 was mostly comedic, reveals a backstory so pitch-black that it feels like you've wandered into GANTZ or Berserk. Unfortunately there are a few weaknesses in the writing that undermine the moral greyness- when a writing fumble makes it alarmingly easy to support a character who is threatening a planet of innocent civilians with nuclear genocide, something has seriously gone wrong. The antagonists in particular suffer, with the titular Veniczar Arcadius in particular being one of the least-intimidating villains I've seen in a long time (largely due to his poor character design, especially the titular Mask which makes him look like a big-headed midget with a Napoleon complex). Nevertheless, the character interaction remains extremely strong and, despite a few fumbles, the moral challenges of the story will really get to you. The issue with the adult content has also been resolved- while Asaga's topless shower scene and Claude's comedic sexual molestation of Captain Shields in part 1 are still there, the truly adult content in part 2 is now appropriately censored, with a free and easy-to-apply patch available for download from the developers' website that restores the ero scenes for consenting adults who want to opt into that.

The best thing about the game is that, despite being of an overall level of quality (especially after the upgrades) worthy of a $20-30 game, it's FREE- now and forever. Thanks to its radical success at gaining funding on Kickstarter, the developers have all the money they need, so the game has already been paid for and is yours, with no DLC or microtransactions in sight. For a game this awesome to be available for zero dinero, you'd have to be a fool NOT to play it.

11199706.review:
I must admit that I generally don't play OELVNs because I find the writing to often be of a pretty poor quality, but the setting here caught my interest and so I decided to give it a shot.

I'm glad I did. 

The game itself is a fairly standard grid-based SRPG. You expend energy by moving and attacking, and so have to weigh the risks of moving closer to allow for greater accuracy, but at the risk of not sinking enemy ships (and of course, the increased accuracy from moving your units closer also applies to the enemies too). There are multiple attack types in the game, each of them playing into the weaknesses of enemy units (though I must admit that I struggled to keep track of which attacks I should be using on the various enemy unit types).

Meanwhile, the story is presented as a fairly typical visual novel. The art looks really great, and the flight suits are wonderfully form-fitting... *ahem* The game is largely unvoiced however, so the only times you'll actually hear the characters speak is when attacking, or being attacked, during combat. 

(As an aside, the music sounds great, but I noticed it can be pretty jarring when they have different songs playing according to whether it's the player's turn or the AI's turn, and that dramatic music you were listening to just suddenly cuts out so the other one can start up.)

11192409.review:
Resumidamente eu me surpreendi por esse jogo estar gratuito. Ele é incrível.

Sem muitos spoilers: Sunrider: First Arrival é um RPG em que as batalhas ocorrem em turno. Nele você estará controlando o capitão Kayto. Depois de sobreviver de um ataque do PACT, você passa a ter no comando uma nave sem bandeira/aliança/nação.
Durante o jogo você vai fazendo diversas aliadas, cada uma com sua história para no final enfrentar o PACT. O jogo também possui um sistema de moralidade, tome cuidado com o que escolher nas respostas.
A dificuldade do jogo vai do fácil ao bem difícil. Fique atento ao que você vai melhorar em sua nave, a Sunrider, ou nas naves de suas aliadas.

A trilha sonora... incrível, uma das melhores tracklists na minha opinião, sendo um dos aspectos mais fortes do jogo - a música tema do jogo é muito boa (Sora no Senritsu - Iced Blade).

Acho que você vai levar de 8 a 10 horas para concluir o jogo na dificuldade mediana.

Recomendo muito este jogo, na minha opinião ele é incrível, e mais incrível ele ser gratuito.

11192218.review:
Definitely enjoyed it, but had some troubles with the battles on Normal mode. I suggest playing in Novel Mode or Easy the first time around, because it's harder than it appears. You also need to save as much CP as you can early on, because the last two missions have a ton of enemies that you need to get rid of quick in order to progress. 

One big problem I had with the battle system is that (in my opinion) the ratio between enemy kills and how much it costs to upgrade wasn't very even. Even if you kill alot of enemies, repair costs at the end can take away a huge chunk of the profits and the number of turns you take in battle also determines the amount of CP you get. So you end up blitzing through battles to complete the mission as fast as possible each time, which nets alot of CP for the Vanguard Cannon and Drones, but you can potentially miss out on alot of money. 

The costly upgrade rates between the Sunrider and the Ryders, plus the necessity of buying missiles means you'll barely be upgrading anything through your playthrough and spending most of them on restocking missiles. The best upgrades I found when playing were increased missile stock for the Sunrider and HP upgrades for everything, since those were cheap. Upgrading anything else such as weapon damage/accuracy/energy, flak and armor were too costly to be effective. Later on in the game you also have to pay to use Repair Drones instead of having them for just 750 CP, and that further depleted the already finite money I had even more. Even at the end of the game I was barely scraping by with barely enough money to afford missiles and could not afford to upgrade anything as the battles just got harder.

Besides the problems I had with the actual battle system and strategy, for a Free English VN this is very very good. It's definitely worth playing and the story is pretty interesting. The VA's are pretty good too; better than what you'd expect for an English VN.

It needs more Icari scenes though. The amount of Icari scenes compared to everyone else made me kinda sad. There were a couple times during the game when you could talk to every Ryder pilot, but Icari wasn't around when I needed her. I'm not sure if it was because of the choices I made in the game or not when getting Icari, but it made me sad when no option to talk to her popped up.

All in all, this is a great game, but start off on Novel Mode or Easy for the first time around so you don't get bogged down in one battle for several hours like I did. Enjoy the story first and foremost before anything else. There was only one doable sidequest in the game, and I'd like to have a few more so players could bolster their resources for later game. 

tl;dr version: It's like Galaxy Angel meets Advance Wars meets Valkyria Chronicles. It's good.

Now the major choices in this game will decide who basically lives and dies, but an important note is there is no right answer.
Justice is a gray line (as in there is no right or wrong answer).

The game part is like Fire Eblem/Final Fansty Tactics. There is no xp system, but there is a money system that is based on how many targets you destoryed and the damage you sustained at the end of a battle. This mony is then used to buy upgrades/missles.

Short Answer:
First 17+ Visual Novel I've seen available on steam (Yes there will be nudity~)

Dating Sim/ Tactical RPG (Mechs, Starships, Tight Space suits that remind me of Muv Luv and Evangelion where do I sign up?)

Very good story as well as a superb soundtrack really sets the mood

Some Heroine Archetypes I noticed: (Osananajimi) Childhood Friend, Kuudere, Dandere, Tsundere, (Hellz yeah!) Pervert (very funny girl xD) and Loli (one thats more annoying then cute)

Partial voiced in English that is pretty good and not ear grating (like almost every hentai that was english dubbed)

Easy to understand combat system (note projectile weapons such as nuke and missles can be shot down by flak so dont believe that 100% hit ratio all the time unless you take down thier flak that is)

10/10 would buy it if they asked for money (which they wont the game is free and will remain the same with the future installments)

Only draw back is it's not fully complete it's a 3 part game and atm the first 2 have been added and in the near future we should see part 3.

Long Answer:
Sunrider: First Arrival has by far surprised me I've been waiting for games like Little Busters and Kanon to get licensed to steam but when I came across this I did not expect to not only get a visual novel but one that comes with tactical RPG gameplay and fanservice. (uncensored in some cases so be carefull if you play this at work then again the sticky note says 17+) It really reminds me of Muv Luv and Baldr Force in terms of Visual Novel but what makes it more interesting is that its voiced partially in english thats not to the point that it grates my ears like most dubbed Hentais. I was also surpised to find out that it wasnt made in Japan so +1 to the developers on this game for not only attempting to make a game but for making it free as well. So you must be asking should I play this game? Is it worth my time? Well if you like playing visual novels or eroge for that matter I really reccomend giving this game a chance also this game is free and from researching it looks like future chapters will still remain free (sorry its not the full game only a small part of it) so I really suggest it. Lastly the gameplay is pretty fun and simple to understand just something I want to note is when you are shooting missles or nukes beware enemys do come with flak which means they are able to shoot some missles if not all of them down so its just something to note that their 100% hit rate doesnt really apply to those types of weapons. The best way to counter that is you get an engineer pretty early in the game I say for the 3rd or 4th battle her name is chigara Ashada I believe that is able to hack in and turn off their flak guns however its for the ships you choose so other enemy ally ships could also shoot them down if they are near the target you are shooting at. In closing I really have to say this despite the game being free if they were to sell this game not saying that they will I would totally buy it.

11177938.review:
怎么说呢，还是好好写一下review吧。
这是一款比较典型的文字冒险游戏，因为目前steam上的只是第一章节，所以虽然有选择项，但不影响主体剧情（除了保护民用船只关的分支）和人物关系。主角叫kayto shields，身为一艘空母舰长（sunrider）的他某日获得了第一个后宫ava（主角以前的学生，舰长副官），从此一发不可收拾的展开了星际后宫之旅（大雾）。当日，主角所在的中立星球cera就被宇宙两大势力之一的PACT（毒菜君主制）入侵，虽然主角神勇的击退了PACT的前卫，但PACT动用了玛莎级主力舰（太阳帝国原罪乱入，游戏内名称legion），使用了夷平大地直接炸平了主角的行星，然后开大秒了cera全军，只有kayto君在主角光环下幸免于难。kayto君从此成为了一为灰色的freelancer，在星际间接取各国的任务，壮大自身的舰载机群（后宫）。
除去文字外，战略面由战棋还原，十分类似于樱花大战的战略面。各种武器对于不同舰艇伤害效果都有很大不同，比如肉搏只能对舰载机造成伤害， 波动和突袭可以有效打击防御较低的舰载机，光能和主炮以及火箭弹导弹能对舰只造成较高伤害。

作为文字冒险类游戏，后宫一定要丰富。
kayto君后宫主要成员：
Ava：主角的学生，副官，青梅竹马般的角色，黑长直，正宫。战略面sunrider驾驶员，初期加入。武器 移动30，主炮70, 光能炮70, 波动40，火箭弹30，导弹30。由于被击毁就游戏结束，而且多半时间被围殴，所以虽然能力很全面，也只能躲在后方用导弹火箭弹打击敌方的巡洋舰主力舰和空母。
Asaga：元气娘，吃货，第二战乱入。真实身分为（？？）。战略面blackjack驾驶员。移动20，光能70，波动50，近战50，突袭30，火箭20。各方面能力均衡，推荐行动力加到120左右应付多种情况。
chigara：乖乖女，天才科学家（黑洞制造者=。=）。第二战结束加入。移动20，光能50，修理80，切断防空40，切断护盾60，提升命中60，动力丧失100。点控加医疗。在中等难度基本全程前期修理，后期控boss....
Icari：傲娇，病娇。凤凰驾驶员。移动10，肉搏40，隐身20，突袭30。纯肉搏机体，高闪避，主要负责清理导弹发射台和杂鱼，一刀一个。推荐加闪避。
claude：痴女。辅助机体。移动30，主炮60，重力60，降低命中30，提升伤害60，恢复护盾60。基本一直在降命中和加伤害，推荐行动力加到120。
sola：三无。远程输出。移动30，觉醒（攻+100%,命中+100）100，主炮100。打法单一，觉醒然后连着输出3回合，加点可以加伤害。
Kryska：同盟军（alliance）的协调官。移动40，火箭弹20，突袭20，主炮60。最后一战来打个酱油的角色....不知道以后章节会不会有所发展。

战略面方面...正常难度已经令人相当绝望了。尤其是护卫民用舰和最后一关。不要吝啬导弹和命令中的先锋炮吧....当然游戏是很人性的，你可以在任何时候调整难度，VN难度下可以随意虐菜...
剧情方面世界设定和人物设定都中规中矩，BGM方面值得表彰。至于H方面，额目前只有asaga洗澡时候"不慎"走光=.=...

总体来说是一款值得一玩的游戏，很期待后续章节（=。=h神马的可以保留就最好了）。

11175445.review:
One of the best free to play games I have played. I would recommend if you are a fan of the following 3 things: anime, space games, and tactics games.

+Fairly good story with character development and choices between battles
+Flows well so that you want to keep playing to see what happens next
+Plenty of spaceships, mechs, missiles, and lasers, fun grid-based tactical combat
+Variety of weapon and ability types with pros/cons to each, making for some strategy
+Many choices of upgrades for your ship and weapon types between battles
+Some voiced dialogue in battles
+FREE to play singleplayer game, can't beat that and I would like to see more

-Graphics are nothing stellar but not bad either, some limited animations
-No voiced dialogue for story or outside of battle
-Voices in battle can be repetitive at times as they occur for every player and enemy action.
-Some character limitations (main character is male, almost every other character is an anime girl)
-No multiplayer (doesn't bother me but some may find that strange in free to play)

11175402.review:
IF youre absolutely starving for both games and cash then I'd recommend playing through this however I couldnt recommend this to anyone with more options available to them. To start with the prose is a bit poor and there were some turns of phrase so odd they forced me to look it up to confirm that it was, in fact, written by americans. The characters are cliches played entirely straight which fits in well with the developers obstinate adherence to the visual novel genre and its painful idosyncrasies. The overarching storyline is somewhat blatantly that of the Star Wars prequels and with the equal lack of orginal or empathizable characters it seems the only creative thought involved was the addition of turn based combat.

The turn based combat in question is much the same as the VN section except that most of its user interface issues are solely its own rather than attributes of the genre. The limited number of your units ,especially in the early stages of the game, leads to relatively short periods of you actually doing anything followed by incredibly long periods of enemies incredibly poorly animated cutscene attacks. The tactics themselves are rather basic though the general lack of explantion of various statistics and the small size of text in what few tooltips exist serves to rather effectively disguise that fact.

Overall the game isn't terrible but your time would be better spent on something with a bit more charm.

11171252.review:
10/10 has giant spaceships, space mechs, giant spaceships fighting space mechs, and boobs. Yep, there are plenty of those carried around by the helpful female cast of the game.

Seriously though Sunrider: First Arrival is a combination of a visual novel and a grid-based, turn-based combat...in space! Yeah! Everyone loves space combat, and if you don't, there's plenty of boobs to carry you along. The game is obviously for you if you are into both genres (especially considering the game is being distributed at the low low price of free), while I can still see fans of either genre enjoying the game's other half.

I am somewhat at a disadvantage here for having almost 0 experience with visual novels (the only thing I know about them is that they come in boobed and non-boobed variants, and the female characters featured, when lined up, display a vast array of hair color envying even rainbows featured in the proudest of gay pride parades). Being unable to tell you how the visual novel experience holds up compared to other visual novels out there, but I can at least tell you that it is functional, for a harem-ish (I assume) with a vast array of female characters archetypes to interact with.

Unfortunately, for players like me, who are drawn in purely to command space fleets and not the promise of boobs (okay, maybe a little bit of boobs too), the game revolves more on its VN experience than its tactical space combats, and those combats only serve to bridge and progress storylines, and act as a means for you to get those cuties to start talking stuff. While the amount of units and their upgrades are for surely not lacking, the overall experience suffered as it had to share its space with the VN part. Still, I'm not complaining here, I got some fun hours out of it (especially if you, like the filthy, brainless peasant I am, drop the difficulty all the way to the lowest and casually mop the space floor with hostile super battleships and carriers and the like in-between rooting for your potential waifu(s))

Overall, considering its price (free), I'd say it's worth a try so long as you are not overly allergic to VNs.

11170778.review:
[h1]Sunrider: An Indie American Visual Novel[/h1]

[quote=BITE ME UNIVERSE]"..this could even be used as a gateway VN..[/quote]

For all sci-fi fans, anime fans, strategy fans, visual novel fans, and story fans, this game will make you fall in love with the genre much further than ever before.

As a beta tester, this game has captivated me in every way possible. The story is full of surprises, and I ususally see everything coming form 5 thousand parsecs away. There was not a single second that I felt like this would be the most predictable story after the first turn of events.

[h1]The Amazing Stretch[/h1]

[b]Going where no man has gone before[/b]
The creator/writer Samu-kun went the extra mile and added something very risky into the story and game. Inside the lore he added a race that would be considered OP, and most writers do not DARE to touch on that subject. As a screenwriter (and writer) myself, I have been told not to for reasons like, "Everything has to have a weakness" and "It would be nothing but a bunch of spoild people running around with no real sense of danger."

Adding this into a game and story is the best thing I have ever scene since writing, and it's not just for one single moment where the, "wise people teach us an important lession about humanity", there is evidence of this race of super humans throughout the game, and it just gets better and better.

If there is one thing to absolutely love about this game, it is how far he stretched the boundries of traditional writing, and successfully incorperating it into the game.

[b]Copyrights? HA![/b]

The Creator has given us, EVERYONE, the ability to use these characters, story, backgrounds, etc. free use to place wherever you want, as long as you don't place a name on it OR sell it. It is ment to be completely free for everyone! They did an amazing job with that, and I hope that other companies follow in this since it is a great idea to allow people to let their creative ideas flow.

[h1]The Good:[/h1]

[b]Story[/b]
The story is everything you expect and more with twists, turns, and the occasional shocker. There isn't a single time when

[b]Strategy[/b]
These battles can be very long and challengeing, causing you to think up strategy like none other. It goes outside the realm of regular strategy, and you RALLY have to think outside the box.

[b]Voice Acting[/b]
There is voice acting but ONLY for battles. Its pretty good, and they hired a decently known name to the gig, so you should recognize her voice when you hear it.

[b]Characters[/b]
They have almost every anime typical character personality in this game. There is a Yandere, Tusndere, Dandere, Gneki, Loli, Kuudere, Nadeshiko, Childhood friend, and...Pervert. Yes, a female pervert.

[h1]The Bad:[/h1]

[b]Writing[/b]
A few pieces of dialogue aren't written all too well. Its a bit cringworthy and could be rewritten. It almost takes you out of the story zone and back into the real world when you read it, somewhat ruining the immersion of the story.

[b]Voice Acting[/b]
It would be nice if the VA went throughout the project, but they are giving this game for free, and don't have the money to do so.

[b]Characters[/b]
This can be seen as a problem for some, so if you don't like what I mentioned above, then you mgiht not like the girls.

[b]Upgrading[/b]
At the start of the game, this can be very difficult since there isn't really much to choose between for upgrades. The cash you have is limited, and upgrades get very expensive after the 3rd upgrade. Only after the battle mentioned below does the cash you get start to increase and become useful, so it can be hard to stick to this game once you reach that point.

[b]Agamemnon Escort[/b]
One of the battles is absolutely ridiculous. Its gonna take a lot of turns to win it on Normal alone, and its almost better to choose a bad path in the story than the good one. Yes, I told you the name of the ship because I think it's fair to warn you all how terrible that battle can be.

BUT...

[b]The Mods:[/b]

This game is 100% moddable. So even if you don't like the way things to, you can always just change the code, or download code through the forums or one of my links on my page (or workshop if they allow you to add it). I will be making a Neko and a -mimi mod for all the characters, so be sure to look out for that one. (^_^)

[h1]In All:[/h1]

This game will not disapoint. And if it does, there are many many many mods to fix that (^_^). I am sure that a lot of fanfic mods will come out, people with their own artwork and own characters to place into the game to change the story and make it ever evolving, the story doesn't have to end once you finish one part of it since there are sure to be many others.

I personally believe that this could even be used as a gateway VN for people who don't know much of the VN scene or have a bias towards it. If you have a friend who likes Turn-based strategy games or Sci-fi games, you might be able to convert them to this game type.

Also, it goes to say that if you know someone who hates the sci-fi genre (like I hate the High Fantasy/Midevil Genre), and they have played games like Agarest: Generations of War or Agarest: Zero, then this game might be able to convert them into a sci-fi fan as well.

This is a completely free game that you can do anything you want with. You can change the story, modify the characters, increase your ship power, and even add you're own arwork into the game.

This is the best idea ever, and I would recomend this game to everyone for the amount of freedom they allow.

It's free, so go ahead and give it a try. 
It's story is decent, and I wish I got through it. 
The combat is quite piss poor. I really wish these types of games just let you skip the tedious combat and read the story...guess I'll just have to go some other place to read the story.
No tooltips of any description. Want to activate stealth? What does it do? You have no god damned idea, so try it...it gives +100% stealth...what does stealth do? Everything can and will still attack it.

There are also performance problems, where it lags when doing to whole battle animation thing. As someone who custom built their computer to run top end games and edit music videos, I find this quite unacceptable, especially from a visual novel-esque game.
This is solved if you used the skip option before entering combat...don't know how to use it during combat...so kinda annoying there.

11165480.review:
I first discovered Sunrider through a gaming news site, during the middle of the Kickstarter. I followed it for a while, eventually downloading the demo. Though nowhere near as refined as it currently is, the combat and the story drew me in, and made me want more. It wasn't a hard decision to back it, in the end, and I haven't regretted it since.

Each of the characters have tropes and cliches making up their general personalities, However, that's not all there is to them. They each have life and depth, which, in my opinion, makes it worth fighting through even the toughest battle, just to see what happens with each of them next.

And believe me, the battles will be tough. Love in Space designed Sunrider to be a very difficult game, in which you always feel as if you're just about to be overwhelmed. I think they have succeeded at this, as I certainly never feel completely at ease during battle.

Still, there are different difficulty levels, if it's too much for you. I don't mind admiting that I switch to Easy on occasion, myself. However, if you're one of those people that finds "nearly being overwhelmed constantly" too easy, there's always the Hard difficulty, which is sure to blow you out of the proverbial water. There's also Visual Novel difficulty, which is good for testing out strategies, or just speeding through the game, if you simply can't wait to get back to the story.

The plot itself is interesting, though if you're a big fan of the genre, you've likely seen the basic idea before. Still, having seen Love in Space's past works, and some of the bigger twists in Sunrider, I can safely say that, by the end, you'll be shocked at where this story goes.

If you're not sure about Visual Novels, Strategy RPGs, or both, I'd like to remind you that the game is free, and not going anywhere. You can try it out at any time, for no cost, so just think it over for a while. If you ever get bored and have nothing better to do, Sunrider might be the right thing to pass the time. And who knows; you might just end up liking it.

11165277.review:
宇宙を舞台に艦を操作し敵を打ち砕け！あとかわいい女子もいるよ！なSLG
SLGとしては非常にわかりやすく操作もぱっと観ただけで理解できます

良かった特徴としては

・インターミッション中の移動はキャラクターの顔アイコンを選ぶことで話が進む
・戦闘システムはEN（行動ポイント制）を使うことで1ターンに攻撃を２回することもできるし移動に全部費やしたりといった戦術の幅広さ
・戦闘目標は「敵の全滅」ではなく特定目標の撃破が多く、基本的に敵が多数の戦闘の中自軍の修理費を抑えつつどれだけ敵を撃破する事で報酬を増やすといった押し引きの判断
・会話分はさすがに文章だけだが戦闘中は攻撃or防御の際に流暢な英語で喋ってくれるのでキャラの個性には一役かっている印象
・女の子は基本カワイイ！ロボはACのような無骨かっこいい！

気になった点として

・戦闘中のグラフィックは良く言えばシンプル、悪く言えば紙芝居に近いので昨今のゲームのような「動き」はあまり期待できない
・広範囲の攻撃を受けた際に狙っていた相手の被弾ダメージは表示されるが周りにいた物へのダメージ表記は無く被弾数のみでわかりにくい
・ステージは選択式で開始前に敵の戦力がどれほどか分からない（大まかな概要説明はある）ので初見はボコボコにやられる事も多い（オートセーブはあるので詰むことはない）
・英語ボイスが、え？君そんな声なの！？というギャップを感じた

戦闘の難易度は全体に高めなように見受けられましたが（難易度選択有）、逆にそれがやりごたえにもなっているのでSLGをやりたい！カワイイ女の子とADVしたいと思った方にはオススメなゲームです

11164238.review:
[h1]苦難を乗り越え、美少女たちと共に母星を取り戻せ！[/h1]
『[b]Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius[/b]』は、米国デベロッパーLove in Spaceが手がける、ターン制戦術SLG+VNです。

[h1]■ ストーリー[/h1]
我々の宇宙とは別の世界……

中立惑星「Cera」は強大な勢力である「PACT」に奇襲を受け、あえなくその力の前に占領されてしまう。プレイヤーとなる、完成目前の最新鋭戦艦「Sunrider」の艦長“Kayto Shields”は、母星を見捨てる苦渋の決断をもって難を逃れ、「PACT」に対抗する手段を求めると共に、その過程で出会った幾人もの少女たちと宇宙を旅することになったのであった……

[h1]■ ゲーム概要[/h1]
本作は船内で各キャラクターに面会して関係を深めていくギャルゲー的なビジュアルノベルパートと、Sunrider及び少女たちの駆る人型メカ“Rider”を率いて敵を撃退する、行動ポイント制のターン制のストラテジーパートにて構成されています。『スーパーロボット大戦』シリーズのオマージュのギャルゲーorアダルトゲームを連想していただくとわかりやすいかもしれません。実際はもっと硬派なストラテジーよりのゲームシステムですが。

無料である本作は何部かで構成される予定の物語の第一部・第二部パートとなっています。ストラテジーパートの内容そのものについては、やりたいこと自体は分かるものの演出で大きくテンポが削がれる面が多い以外は、可もなく不可もなく。行動ポイント制なので1ターン内で複数行動がデフォルトで可能な点などはありますが、基本的にはアベレージ程度なので割愛します。ただし、敵の物量も多く、単純な敵全滅マップが少ないのもあって難易度は『スーパーロボット大戦』シリーズに比べて大幅に高いので注意しましょう。

ビジュアルノベル部分については、CGのレベルこそ日本のそれと比べると見劣るする点も多いですが、十分日本的なものとして見ても面白いテキスト側が、キャラクターの魅力を引き出して次作以降への興味を持たせられるレベルになっているのは注目です。ただしエンディングが続編前提で、完全にぶつ切りになってしまっているのは、良くあるクリフハンガー展開とはいえ少々人によっては気になるかもです。

[h1]■ ムフフなシーンもあるよ！実はSteam初？[/h1]
本作の最大の特徴は1部の1枚絵のCGシーンにおいて所謂「乳首券」が発行、要するにヒロインの女の子達の隠されていない裸が見られる点であります。恐らく日本風の2D絵でそれが許可された作品はSteam上においては2014年7月現在これが初であり、Steamで配信可能なゲームのレーティングに一石を投じるものとなっております。

所謂ソフ倫のR指定（15禁、ソフトなヌード）までは許諾されうるという推測が引き出されたのは大きいのではないかと思います。また、性的な要素を含むシーンは第二部以降更に増え、Steam配信版の現在レベル+αの表現に収まる版と、公式で配布されるより露骨な、所謂アダルトなシーンを含む版とに別れました。
（筆注：結局局部描写なければ問題なく性交シーンでもOK出るというのが2016年末の基準みたいです）

とは言え、差分は[url=sunrider-vn.com/sunriderpage/]パッチとして公式で配布[/url]されているため必要な方も安心です。問題の場面は1シーン、あるキャラの濡れ場の有無(CG基本2枚)のみですが。

-----
図らずしてある種のマイルストーンになってしまった本作、今後の経過も含めて、確認のために触られてみるのもいいかもしれません。多少なりとも英語が読めるのであれば、珍しさも含めてその独特の魅力は、おすすめに値するものでしょう。

[h1]■ パラレルワールド舞台のスピンオフ『Sunrider Academy』発売されました。[/h1]
http://store.steampowered.com/app/340730/

[h1]■ 第三部「Liberation Day」発売されました。[/h1]
http://store.steampowered.com/app/358750/
なお、本作を第三部「Liberation Day」上で追加シナリオとして動かすModがリリースされています。グラフィックは一部立ち絵やイベントCGとの兼ね合いで本作そのままになっていますが、特に戦闘面で相当システムが快適になっているのはかなりの魅力です。（戦闘時ボイスも日本語になります）第三部本編との共存が可能なのも嬉しい所でしょう。インストール時に本作のデータを要求されるのだけは注意です。Modのダウンロードは[url=forum.loveinspace.moe/thread/241/libday-first-arrival-mask-arcadius]こちらから[/url]。

11162620.review:
Al ver las imagenes de este juego pense que seria una visual novel free to play como cualquier otra de las pocas que he jugado anteriormente, pero luego me di cuenta que es mas que eso, ya que posee un sistema de combate por turnos bastante entretenido y sencillo, no es necesario tener experiencia previa en juegos de combate por turnos para adaptarse a este.

El juego en si me parece una combinacion entre FTL (Faster Than Light) y Evangelion (Si,el anime), ya que el juego consiste en ser el capitan de una nave e ir tomando decisiones como que debe ser mejorado en la nave, que comprar, hacia que planeta ir, etc. Y tambien te iras encontrando con unos pilotos de mechas que casualmente son unas niñas quizas menores de edad (por esto me recuerda a Evangelion) las cuales se iran uniendo a tu tripulacion y asi obtendras mas apoyo y poder durante las batallas (que al principio son sencillas y crees que todas seran igual pero luego te das cuenta que no es asi)

Encontre varios detalles que me agradaron del juego como la excelente musica de fondo durante las batallas que te hace sentir la adrenalina de que van a destruir tu crucero, pero al igual que buenos detalles tambien hay malos detalles como el pesimo diseño de naves y mechas que parecen hechos con Legos.

El juego actualmente esta en fase beta y tengo fe en que pronto salga una buena traduccion(hay que tener un buen dominio de ingles para entender los dialogos), que se vaya subiendo contenido adicional con el tiempo y obviamente que arreglen los bugs que tiene.

EN CONCLUSION: Si, recomiendo este juego, sin importar que no hayas jugado anteriormente un juego de ataques por turnos o una visual novel este es un must play principalmente porque ES GRATIS.

11160894.review:
I'm a Sunrider Kickstarter backer.  This version appears to be the latest beta with some adjustments to the upgrade costs.  The story and tactical gameplay are fun, with lots of optons for different tactics and upgrade paths.  The difficulty settings allow for easy or extremely challenging battles, so you should be able to find a play style that appeals to you.  You may want to lower the music volume so you can hear the pilots' commentary during battle.

You will need to learn where the game expects you to click when selecting units for command or targetting, and there is some lag when many units are on the battle screen.  There is also (at the moment) a lack of documentation on some of the options available to the support units, but their use should become clear with a little experimentation.  I expect most of these issues to be addressed as the game continues development.

Highly recommended!

11160309.review:
Sunrider: First Arrival is a Visual Novel style RPG Tactics, it is a science fiction type of game. Well, if you think this is just another of those lousy and cheesy anime game. You are wrong. Believe me, you are wrong. This is a tactics game, if you ever play Final Fantasy Tactics or Agarest: Generation of War, it is that type of game.

The gameplay mechanic is very fun i might say, you can upgrade your ship or your mecha crew, like you want to make it stronger, or deals much more damage. The thing that you can upgrade is a lot. The battle mechanic is simple but fun, basically you got multiple skill and type of attack, like long range beam attack, gun attack, laser attack, rocket, and you need to use the right type of attack at the right type of the enemy, if for example you are facing the cruiser with alot of armor, you cannot just use the gun attack because the gun attack deal less damage against the enemy with alot of armor, or if your enemy is a light mecha, you can't use a long range beam attack against them since they be able to dodge it easily.

Outside of the combat, you got some Mass Effect ish kinda interaction in your ship, you talked to your crew try to get to know them. The story is very good, i might say it is like Mass Effect in the way that there's some choice that seems right, but when you choose it some innocent people die because of it. The Lore is deep also, i don't think there's good or bad here, It just politics. 

Soo, well its free. From the quality alone this game is very good that is on par with the game that cost 15 dollars. But it is free. Recommended to the highest level !!

11158252.review:
For a free game, it's nice. I was impressed with the quality of the music and sounds. The art is crisper than it appears in the videos, but I was still a bit disappointed in the minimal animation. The game is story driven so you will find yourself clicking through a lot of exposition between stages. The story doesn't do it for me personally but some might enjoy it more.. far it seems pretty linear, we'll see how much they let your choices affect dispositions/outcomes by the end. The strategy is not incredibly complex but provides some casual fun with a fair amount of choices via upgrades system. There are three levels of difficulty though I don't know how they scale yet. Unfortunately it's a purely single player experience, but definitely worth a play.

One big gripe I have is that I wish they would change is to make the unit-select work by clicking on the whole tile rather than the unit outlines. It's very easy to misclick and it makes the interface feel sticky. The deck select seems needlessly complex as well-- Same with cutscenes for every attack, although I do appreciate that you can click through them.

11157485.review:
Since Sunrider's original release, things have changed, the combat system grew more complicated and challenging, and the story stopped being developed as well as it had been. I, like many of the other kickstarter backers for this game, didn't back this game for it's combat systems, though they were interesting; I backed the game for it's promise of a sweeping space opera, what we have received is not that. The story is barely there (try playing with dev cheats on and skip the battles, the story takes just a fraction of the normal time) the characters feel like cardboard cut outs and the combat is so clunky and boring it just saps all enthusiasm for the rest of the game. I can no longer recommend this game in this state or any state that follows this path, only a rewrite of the game from the end of part one could possibly save it now.






Original, now out of date review.

Don't let my complete lack of gameplay time fool you, as a Kickstarter backer for Sunrider I've been playing various versions of Sunrider since the first demo last year. The current beta version of the game has around 10 hours worth of content split between turn based combat and visual novel sections. The Visual Novel sections work as expected of a typical Japanese VN with the occasional choices that can change outcomes or allow you to learn more about your enemies or the lore. The Turn based combat sections put you in command of the Sunrider and various Ryders (big robots). Each Ryder has it's own weapons and abilities and while learning what each one does can be a pain (the lack of tooltips is being worked on) once you've mastered them you'll be a force to be reckoned with. The turn based combat also includes voice acting by professional and amatuer voice actors and actresses. Combat difficulty is still being worked on but at the moment ranges from super easy in the form of "Visual Novel" difficulty to the very difficult "Hard" difficulty. I must also make note of the amazing soundtrack which makes each and every moment of the game feel amazing. 

Note: Keep in mind that the game is still in a beta state and could still include bugs.

For the Sensitive Gamer: Sunrider includes some brief sexual content and nudity, if you're offended by these things, you've been warned. While the content is minimal in this version of the game, it will become more prominent in later versions, however an "all ages" version is planned for eventual release.
